seo.title: Wallpaper Calculator Online - Calculate Wallpaper Quantity for Room | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online wallpaper calculator for accurate calculation of wallpaper rolls needed for room. Accounts for room dimensions, windows, doors, roll sizes and pattern matching reserve.

overview.title: Wallpaper Calculator Online
overview.content: Online wallpaper calculator will help calculate required number of wallpaper rolls for room. Accounts for room dimensions, wall height, window and door sizes, wallpaper roll sizes and reserve for pattern matching and possible defects.
overview.additionalContent: Wallpaper calculator uses accurate formulas for calculating material quantity accounting for room type, pasting method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various wallpaper types: vinyl, non-woven, paper, textile. Calculation formula: Number of Rolls = (Wall Area - Openings Area) × (1 + Reserve / 100) / Roll Area.

calculationExamples.title: Wallpaper Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of wallpaper quantity calculation for various rooms and wallpaper types:

example1.title: Example 1: Bedroom 4×3 meters
example1.description: Standard bedroom with ceiling height 2.7 m, vinyl wallpaper
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window: 1.2×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Reserve: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Openings Area: 1.2×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 3.6 m²
Useful Area: 37.8 - 3.6 = 34.2 m²
Roll Area: 0.53 × 10.05 = 5.33 m²
With Reserve: 34.2 × 1.1 = 37.62 m²
Rolls: 37.62 / 5.33 = 7.06 ≈ 8 rolls
example1.note: Standard bedroom, recommended to take 8-9 rolls with small reserve

example2.title: Example 2: Living Room 5×4 meters
example2.description: Large living room with ceiling height 2.7 m, non-woven wallpaper with pattern
example2.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 pcs 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Reserve: 15%
example2.note: For patterned wallpaper increased reserve 15% is recommended for matching

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3×2.5 meters
example3.description: Kitchen with ceiling height 2.5 m, moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window: 1.2×1.2 m
Door: 0.8×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Reserve: 10%
example3.note: For kitchen moisture-resistant wallpaper that is easy to wash is recommended

example4.title: Example 4: Children's Room 4×3.5 meters
example4.description: Children's room with ceiling height 2.6 m, paper wallpaper
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.6 m
Window: 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Reserve: 10%
example4.note: For children's room eco-friendly paper wallpaper is recommended

example5.title: Example 5: Living Room with Wide Rolls
example5.description: Large living room 6×5 meters with ceiling height 3 m, wide wallpaper
example5.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 3 m
Windows: 3 pcs 1.5×2.0 m
Door: 1.0×2.1 m
Roll: 1.06×10.05 m
Reserve: 10%
example5.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (6 + 5) × 3 = 66 m²
Openings Area: 3×1.5×2.0 + 1.0×2.1 = 11.1 m²
Useful Area: 66 - 11.1 = 54.9 m²
Roll Area: 1.06 × 10.05 = 10.65 m²
With Reserve: 54.9 × 1.1 = 60.39 m²
Rolls: 60.39 / 10.65 = 5.67 ≈ 6 rolls
example5.note: Wide rolls allow reducing number of joints and simplifying pasting

example6.title: Example 6: Hallway 2×1.5 meters
example6.description: Small hallway with ceiling height 2.5 m, washable wallpaper
example6.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Roll: 0.53×10.05 m
Reserve: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (2 + 1.5) × 2.5 = 17.5 m²
Openings Area: 0.9×2.0 = 1.8 m²
Useful Area: 17.5 - 1.8 = 15.7 m²
Roll Area: 0.53 × 10.05 = 5.33 m²
With Reserve: 15.7 × 1.1 = 17.27 m²
Rolls: 17.27 / 5.33 = 3.24 ≈ 4 rolls
example6.note: For hallway wear-resistant washable wallpaper is recommended

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper quantity for room?
faqItems.a: To calculate wallpaper measure room length, width and height, specify sizes of all windows and doors, select wallpaper roll size and reserve percentage. Calculator will automatically calculate required number of rolls.

faqItems.q: How many wallpaper rolls needed for room?
faqItems.a: Number of rolls depends on room dimensions, ceiling height, number of windows and doors. For standard room 4×3 meters with ceiling height 2.7 m need approximately 6-8 rolls of standard size (0.53×10.05 m) accounting for 10% reserve.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper accounting for windows and doors?
faqItems.a: When calculating wallpaper subtract area of all windows and doors from total wall area. This allows getting accurate useful area for pasting and avoid material overconsumption.

faqItems.q: What wallpaper reserve is needed?
faqItems.a: Reserve 10-15% is recommended for regular wallpaper and 15-20% for patterned wallpaper requiring matching. Reserve accounts for pattern matching, defects and possible errors when pasting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for bedroom?
faqItems.a: For bedroom measure room dimensions, specify windows and doors. Select wallpaper type (vinyl, non-woven, paper). Add 10% reserve for regular wallpaper or 15% for patterned wallpaper.

faqItems.q: What is wallpaper rapport?
faqItems.a: Wallpaper rapport is repeating pattern on wallpaper sheet. When calculating patterned wallpaper need to account for rapport for correct matching, which increases material consumption by 15-20%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for living room?
faqItems.a: For living room measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. For large room better use wide rolls (0.7×10.05 m or 1.06×10.05 m) to reduce number of joints.

faqItems.q: How many meters in wallpaper roll?
faqItems.a: Standard wallpaper roll has size 0.53×10.05 meters (area 5.33 m²). Also exist wide rolls 0.7×10.05 m (7.04 m²) and very wide 1.06×10.05 m (10.65 m²), as well as long rolls 0.53×15.0 m (7.95 m²).

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen recommended to use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper. Measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Add 10-15% reserve for pattern matching and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What is difference between vinyl and non-woven wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Vinyl wallpaper have PVC coating, moisture-resistant and washable. Non-woven wallpaper are more durable, breathable, better hide wall irregularities. Quantity calculation for both types is same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For bathroom use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper. Measure wall area, subtract door area. Add 15% reserve for increased humidity. Account that bathroom usually has smaller wall area.

faqItems.q: How much does wallpaper pasting cost?
faqItems.a: Wallpaper cost depends on type, manufacturer and design. Paper wallpaper cost from $2 to $10/roll, vinyl - from $5 to $30/roll, non-woven - from $8 to $50/roll. Calculate number of rolls and multiply by price per roll.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for children's room?
faqItems.a: For children's room measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Recommended to use eco-friendly paper wallpaper or vinyl wallpaper with safety certificate. Add 10% reserve.

faqItems.q: Do I need to account for windows and doors when calculating wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Yes, definitely account for all windows and doors when calculating wallpaper. Subtracting openings area from total wall area allows getting accurate useful area for pasting and avoid material overconsumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate patterned wallpaper?
faqItems.a: When calculating patterned wallpaper account for rapport - repeating pattern. Increase reserve to 15-20% for pattern matching. Also account for pasting direction - vertical or horizontal.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for hallway?
faqItems.a: For hallway measure length and width, ceiling height. Account for all doors in hallway. Recommended to use wear-resistant washable wallpaper for high traffic. Add 10-15% reserve.

faqItems.q: What are wide wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Wide wallpaper have width 0.7 m or 1.06 m instead of standard 0.53 m. They allow reducing number of joints when pasting and speed up process. Quantity calculation is done by same formula.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for balcony?
faqItems.a: For balcony measure wall area. Use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper for exterior work or insulated balconies. Account for temperature variations. Add 15% reserve for complex shapes.

faqItems.q: How much wallpaper needed per 1 m² of wall?
faqItems.a: Number of wallpaper rolls per 1 m² depends on roll size. Standard roll 0.53×10.05 m covers 5.33 m², so per 1 m² need approximately 0.19 roll (1 / 5.33). In practice for 1 m² need about 0.2 roll accounting for reserve.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for studio?
faqItems.a: For studio measure area of all walls. Account for all windows and doors. Select wallpaper type depending on zoning. For open spaces better use wide rolls. Add 10-15% reserve.

faqItems.q: What are non-woven wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Non-woven wallpaper are made from non-woven material based on cellulose. They are durable, breathable, well hide wall irregularities. Quantity calculation is same as for regular wallpaper.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for toilet?
faqItems.a: For toilet measure wall area. Subtract door area. Use moisture-resistant vinyl wallpaper. Account for small room area. Add 10% reserve for regular installation.

faqItems.q: What wallpaper is better for bedroom?
faqItems.a: For bedroom recommended to use paper wallpaper (eco-friendly, breathable) or non-woven wallpaper (durable, hide irregularities). Vinyl wallpaper suit for wet rooms. Quantity calculation is same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for living room with high ceilings?
faqItems.a: For living room with high ceilings measure wall height from floor to ceiling. Calculate wall area by standard formula. Account that for high ceilings may require more material for pattern matching. Add 15% reserve.

faqItems.q: What are paper wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Paper wallpaper are simplest and most eco-friendly wallpaper type. They are breathable, inexpensive, but less durable and moisture-resistant than vinyl or non-woven. Quantity calculation is same as for other types.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For apartment calculate area of each room separately. Use different wallpaper types for different rooms (moisture-resistant for kitchen and bathroom, eco-friendly for bedroom). Sum results for total number of rolls.

faqItems.q: Do I need to buy wallpaper with reserve?
faqItems.a: Yes, definitely buy wallpaper with 10-15% reserve for pattern matching, defects and possible errors when pasting. Reserve helps avoid situation when one roll is missing and hard to find exact same in store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for hallway?
faqItems.a: For hallway measure wall area. Account for all doors. Recommended to use wear-resistant washable wallpaper for high traffic. Add 10-15% reserve for pattern matching.

faqItems.q: What are textile wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Textile wallpaper are made from fabric (silk, linen, jute) on paper or non-woven base. They are decorative, expensive, require careful pasting. Quantity calculation is same as for regular wallpaper.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for house?
faqItems.a: For house calculate area of each room separately. Use different wallpaper types for different rooms. Sum results for total number of rolls. Account that for large rooms better use wide rolls.

faqItems.q: What is standard wallpaper width?
faqItems.a: Standard wallpaper width is 0.53 meters (53 cm). Also exist wide wallpaper with width 0.7 m (70 cm) and very wide 1.06 m (106 cm). Length of standard roll usually 10.05 m or 15.0 m.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wallpaper for room with niches?
faqItems.a: For room with niches measure total wall area, then add area of niches and projections. Account for complex shapes and corners. Add 15% reserve for complex shapes and pattern matching in corners.

faqItems.q: What are washable wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Washable wallpaper are wallpaper with protective coating that can be washed with wet cloth. Usually these are vinyl or non-woven wallpaper with special coating. They suit for kitchens, hallways and other rooms with high soiling.

overview.title: Paint Calculator
overview.content: Online paint calculator will help calculate required paint quantity for walls. Accounts for room dimensions, number of layers, consumption rate and reserve for losses.
overview.additionalContent: Paint calculator uses accurate formulas for calculating material quantity accounting for surface type, application method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various paint types: water-based, oil-based, acrylic, latex. Calculation formula: Total Paint Quantity = (Wall Area - Doors and Windows Area) × Consumption Rate (L/m²) × Number of Layers × (1 + Reserve / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Paint Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of paint quantity calculation for various rooms and paint types:

example1.title: Example 1: Room 3×4 meters
example1.description: Standard room with ceiling height 2.7 m, water-based paint
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows and Doors Area: 4.5 m²
Number of Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Useful Area: 37.8 - 4.5 = 33.3 m²
Consumption per Layer: 33.3 × 0.12 = 4.0 L
Total Consumption: 4.0 × 2 × 1.1 = 8.8 L
example1.note: Standard room for painting, recommended to take 4-5 cans with small reserve

example2.title: Example 2: Large Living Room
example2.description: Spacious living room with large windows, acrylic paint
example2.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 3 m
Windows and Doors Area: 12 m²
Number of Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 0.15 L/m²
Reserve: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (6 + 5) × 3 = 66 m²
Useful Area: 66 - 12 = 54 m²
Consumption per Layer: 54 × 0.15 = 8.1 L
Total Consumption: 8.1 × 2 × 1.15 = 18.6 L
example2.note: For large rooms recommended to increase reserve to 15%

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen with Tiles
example3.description: Kitchen where part of walls covered with tiles, only upper part for painting
example3.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Area Under Tiles: 15 m²
Windows and Doors Area: 3 m²
Number of Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Area for Painting: 37.8 - 15 - 3 = 19.8 m²
Consumption per Layer: 19.8 × 0.12 = 2.4 L
Total Consumption: 2.4 × 2 × 1.1 = 5.3 L
example3.note: For kitchen better choose washable paint

example4.title: Example 4: Bedroom, One Layer
example4.description: Bedroom with good surface preparation, finish layer
example4.input:
Length: 4.5 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Windows and Doors Area: 5 m²
Number of Layers: 1
Consumption Rate: 0.1 L/m²
Reserve: 5%
example4.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4.5 + 3.5) × 2.5 = 40 m²
Useful Area: 40 - 5 = 35 m²
Consumption per Layer: 35 × 0.1 = 3.5 L
Total Consumption: 3.5 × 1 × 1.05 = 3.7 L
example4.note: For finish layer consumption is usually less

example5.title: Example 5: Children's Room
example5.description: Children's room with quality coating requirement
example5.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows and Doors Area: 6 m²
Number of Layers: 3
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 15%
example5.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3.5) × 2.7 = 40.5 m²
Useful Area: 40.5 - 6 = 34.5 m²
Consumption per Layer: 34.5 × 0.12 = 4.1 L
Total Consumption: 4.1 × 3 × 1.15 = 14.1 L
example5.note: For children's room recommended to use safe paints and increase number of layers

example6.title: Example 6: Hallway
example6.description: Narrow hallway with minimal windows
example6.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 1.2 m, Height: 2.5 m
Doors Area: 2 m²
Number of Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (6 + 1.2) × 2.5 = 36 m²
Useful Area: 36 - 2 = 34 m²
Consumption per Layer: 34 × 0.12 = 4.1 L
Total Consumption: 4.1 × 2 × 1.1 = 9.0 L
example6.note: For hallways better choose paints with increased wear resistance

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint quantity?
faqItems.a: To calculate paint use formula: (Wall Area - Windows and Doors Area) × Consumption Rate (L/m²) × Number of Layers × (1 + Reserve / 100). Consumption rate usually is 0.1-0.15 L/m².

faqItems.q: What is paint consumption per 1 m²?
faqItems.a: Paint consumption is usually 0.1-0.15 L/m² for one layer. For water-based paint consumption may be lower, for oil-based - higher.

faqItems.q: How many paint layers are needed?
faqItems.a: Usually 2 paint layers are enough for quality coating. For dark colors over light may require more layers.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for ceiling?
faqItems.a: To calculate paint for ceiling use ceiling area (length × width) instead of wall area. Formula: Ceiling Area × Consumption Rate × Number of Layers × (1 + Reserve / 100). For ceiling usually 2 paint layers are required.

faqItems.q: What paint reserve should be taken?
faqItems.a: Reserve 10-15% of calculated paint quantity is recommended. This compensates losses during application, trimming and possible calculation errors. For large rooms reserve can be increased to 15-20%.

faqItems.q: What is difference between water-based and acrylic paint?
faqItems.a: Water-based paint is general name for water paints, including acrylic. Acrylic paint has acrylic binders and more durable. For calculation use same consumption rate 0.1-0.15 L/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for facade?
faqItems.a: Facade paint calculation is similar to interior work, but consumption rate may be higher (0.15-0.2 L/m²) due to surface irregularities. Account for area of all building walls and subtract windows and doors.

faqItems.q: How much does room painting cost?
faqItems.a: Painting cost depends on paint type (from $2 to $20 per liter), room area and number of layers. Use calculator to determine paint quantity, then multiply by price per liter.

faqItems.q: What paint to choose for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen choose washable paint with high moisture and grease resistance. Consumption of such paints is usually standard - 0.12-0.15 L/m². 2 layers are recommended for protection.

faqItems.q: Do walls need priming before painting?
faqItems.a: Priming is mandatory for new walls and recommended for old. Primer reduces paint consumption by 10-20% and improves adhesion. Paint calculation doesn't include primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for irregular shape room?
faqItems.a: For irregular shape room measure each wall separately, then sum areas. Formula: Area = (Wall1 + Wall2 + Wall3 + Wall4) - Windows and Doors Area. Use this area in calculator.

faqItems.q: What paint consumption for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For bathroom use moisture-resistant paint with consumption 0.12-0.15 L/m². 2-3 layers are recommended for moisture protection. Account for small room and possible wall irregularities.

faqItems.q: How long does paint dry between layers?
faqItems.a: Water-based paint dries 2-4 hours at room temperature. Acrylic paint dries 4-6 hours. Oil-based paint dries 24-48 hours. Account for drying time when planning work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for room with arches?
faqItems.a: For room with arches measure arch area separately as part of walls or subtract from total area. Arches usually occupy small area and don't significantly affect calculation. Use standard formula.

faqItems.q: Does paint color affect consumption?
faqItems.a: Dark paints may require 3 layers instead of 2 for even coverage of light surface. Light paints cover well with 2 layers. Account for this in calculation, increasing number of layers for dark colors.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for wooden walls?
faqItems.a: For wooden walls consumption rate is higher due to absorbency - 0.15-0.2 L/m². Pre-priming is recommended. Usually 2-3 paint layers are required for quality coating.

faqItems.q: What tool affects paint consumption?
faqItems.a: Brush consumes 10-15% more paint than roller. Spray gun is most economical - 5-10% less consumption. For calculation use average consumption rate accounting for tool.

faqItems.q: Can old paint be used?
faqItems.a: Old paint can be used if not thickened and color hasn't changed. Before using check consistency and stir. Old paint consumption may be slightly higher.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for drywall?
faqItems.a: For drywall consumption rate is standard - 0.12 L/m², but pre-priming is mandatory. Usually 2 paint layers are enough. Account for area of all drywall sheets.

faqItems.q: How much paint needed for one room?
faqItems.a: For standard room 3×4 m with ceiling height 2.7 m need approximately 8-10 liters of paint for 2 layers. Accurate calculation can be obtained using calculator with your room parameters.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint accounting for doors?
faqItems.a: Doors area is subtracted from total wall area before calculation. Measure width and height of each door, multiply and subtract from wall area. Standard door occupies 1.8-2 m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for balcony?
faqItems.a: For balcony measure area of all walls and ceiling if it will be painted. Consumption rate is standard - 0.12 L/m². Account that for balcony better use facade paint resistant to temperature variations.

faqItems.q: What is paint hiding power?
faqItems.a: Hiding power is paint ability to cover surface color. High hiding power means lower consumption. Hiding power is indicated on paint can and affects consumption rate. Higher hiding power means less consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for textured ceiling?
faqItems.a: For textured ceiling consumption rate is higher by 20-30% due to increased surface area. Use consumption rate 0.15-0.18 L/m² instead of standard. Textured surface requires more paint.

faqItems.q: Should paint be diluted with water?
faqItems.a: Water-based paint can be diluted with water up to 5-10% for application convenience. Dilution slightly increases consumption but improves flow. When calculating account for standard consumption rate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for room with columns?
faqItems.a: For room with columns measure column area as part of walls (perimeter × height) and add to total wall area. Columns require standard paint consumption rate - 0.12 L/m².

faqItems.q: How much paint consumed for 3 meter high walls?
faqItems.a: Wall height affects area but not consumption rate. For room 4×3 m with height 3 m wall area = 2 × (4 + 3) × 3 = 42 m². With consumption rate 0.12 L/m² and 2 layers need: 42 × 0.12 × 2 × 1.1 = 11.1 L.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for room with bay window?
faqItems.a: For room with bay window measure area of all walls, including bay window walls. Bay window adds additional wall area. Use calculator with full area of all surfaces for painting.

faqItems.q: Does temperature affect paint consumption?
faqItems.a: Air temperature affects drying time but slightly on consumption. At high temperature paint dries faster and may require additional layer. At low temperature consumption may slightly increase.

faqItems.q: How to calculate paint for room with niches?
faqItems.a: For room with niches measure wall area of niches and add to total area. Niches increase area for painting. Use standard consumption rate - 0.12 L/m² for all surfaces.

faqItems.q: How much paint needed for entire apartment painting?
faqItems.a: For entire apartment painting calculate each room separately and sum results. Average three-room apartment requires 40-60 liters of paint for all walls depending on room areas.

calculationExamples.title: Tile Adhesive Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of tile adhesive quantity calculation for various rooms and tile types:

example1.title: Example 1: Bathroom 3×2 meters
example1.description: Standard bathroom with ceramic tile 30×30 cm
example1.input:
Floor Area: 6 m²
Openings Area: 0.5 m²
Tile Size: 0.09 m² (30×30 cm)
Grout Width: 2 mm
Consumption Rate: 4 kg/m²
Reserve: 10%
example1.calculation:
Useful Area: 6 - 0.5 = 5.5 m²
Adhesive Consumption: 5.5 × 4 = 22 kg
With Reserve: 22 × 1.1 = 24.2 kg
Packages (25 kg): 24.2 / 25 = 0.97 ≈ 1 package
example1.note: Standard bathroom, recommended to take 1-2 packages with small reserve

With Reserve: 9.45 × 1.1 = 10.4 kg

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile adhesive quantity?
faqItems.a: To calculate tile adhesive measure floor area, subtract openings area, multiply by consumption rate (usually 3-6 kg/m²) and add reserve 10-15%. Calculator will automatically perform all calculations.

faqItems.q: How much adhesive needed per 1 m² of tile?
faqItems.a: Tile adhesive consumption is usually 3-5 kg/m² for standard tile size 30×30 cm. For large-format tile (60×60 cm and larger) consumption may be 5-7 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for mosaic?
faqItems.a: For mosaic adhesive consumption is higher due to large number of joints. Recommended to use consumption rate 5-7 kg/m² and increase reserve to 15-20% for fitting.

faqItems.q: What adhesive is better for porcelain stoneware?
faqItems.a: For porcelain stoneware recommended to use reinforced cement adhesive or dispersion adhesive with increased adhesion. Consumption is 5-6 kg/m² for tile size 60×60 cm.

faqItems.q: Should grout width be accounted for when calculating adhesive?
faqItems.a: Yes, grout width affects adhesive consumption. Wider grout means more adhesive consumption. For grout 2-3 mm consumption is standard, for grout 5 mm and more consumption increases by 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For bathroom use moisture-resistant dispersion adhesive. Measure floor area, subtract openings area. For standard tile 30×30 cm use consumption rate 4-5 kg/m² with reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much does tile adhesive package weigh?
faqItems.a: Standard tile adhesive package weighs 25 kg. Also exist packages of 5 kg, 10 kg and 50 kg. For large volumes better buy packages of 25 or 50 kg.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for floor?
faqItems.a: For floor measure area in square meters. Account that for floor usually more adhesive is required due to greater load. Use consumption rate 4-6 kg/m² depending on tile size.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls calculation is similar to floor calculation. Measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. For walls can use slightly lower consumption rate 3-4 kg/m² for standard tile.

faqItems.q: What is difference between cement and dispersion adhesive?
faqItems.a: Cement adhesive is universal, suitable for dry rooms. Dispersion adhesive is moisture-resistant, suitable for bathrooms and kitchens. Consumption for both types is approximately same - 3-5 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen use moisture-resistant dispersion adhesive or reinforced cement. Measure floor area, subtract openings area. For standard tile use consumption rate 4-5 kg/m² with reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much adhesive needed for tile 60×60 cm?
faqItems.a: For tile 60×60 cm adhesive consumption is usually 5-6 kg/m². This is related to large tile size and need for thicker adhesive layer for reliable fixation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for hallway?
faqItems.a: For hallway measure floor area. Account for high traffic, use wear-resistant adhesive. For standard tile use consumption rate 4-5 kg/m² with reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: Should adhesive be bought with reserve?
faqItems.a: Yes, definitely buy adhesive with reserve 10-15% for fitting, defects and possible errors during installation. Reserve helps avoid situation when one bag is missing and hard to find exact same in store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for ceramic tile?
faqItems.a: For standard size ceramic tile (30×30 cm) use consumption rate 3-4 kg/m². Measure floor area, subtract openings area, multiply by consumption rate and add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is epoxy adhesive for tile?
faqItems.a: Epoxy adhesive is two-component adhesive for complex operating conditions. It is very strong, moisture-resistant, but expensive. Consumption is 5-7 kg/m². Used for industrial rooms and complex conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for toilet?
faqItems.a: For toilet measure floor area. Use moisture-resistant dispersion adhesive. Account for small room area. For standard tile use consumption rate 4 kg/m² with reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: How much does tile adhesive cost?
faqItems.a: Tile adhesive cost depends on type, manufacturer and quality. Cement adhesive costs from $2 to $10 per bag (25 kg), dispersion - from $5 to $15 per bag, epoxy - from $20 to $50 per bag.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for balcony?
faqItems.a: For balcony use frost-resistant adhesive for exterior work or insulated balconies. Measure floor area. Account for temperature variations. Use consumption rate 4-5 kg/m² with reserve 15% for complex conditions.

faqItems.q: What adhesive consumption for tile on walls?
faqItems.a: For walls adhesive consumption is usually slightly less than for floor - 3-4 kg/m² for standard tile 30×30 cm. This is related to that on walls load is less and can use thinner adhesive layer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for large tile?
faqItems.a: For large tile (60×60 cm and larger) adhesive consumption increases to 5-7 kg/m². This is related to need for thicker adhesive layer for reliable fixation of large tiles. Add reserve 15%.

faqItems.q: What is polyurethane adhesive for tile?
faqItems.a: Polyurethane adhesive is elastic one-component adhesive for large tiles and complex conditions. It is very elastic, moisture-resistant. Consumption is 3-4 kg/m². More expensive than cement adhesive.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For apartment calculate area of each room separately. Use different adhesive types for different rooms (moisture-resistant for bathroom and kitchen, regular for living rooms). Sum results for total number of packages.

faqItems.q: Should tile size be accounted for when calculating adhesive?
faqItems.a: Yes, tile size directly affects adhesive consumption. Larger tile means more adhesive consumption. For small tile (up to 20×20 cm) consumption 3-4 kg/m², for medium (30×30 cm) - 4-5 kg/m², for large (60×60 cm and larger) - 5-7 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for complex shapes?
faqItems.a: For complex shapes (niches, projections, corners) add reserve 15-20% to regular calculation. Account for need of tile fitting and additional adhesive consumption in hard-to-reach places.

faqItems.q: How much adhesive needed for tile 120×60 cm?
faqItems.a: For very large tile 120×60 cm adhesive consumption is 6-7 kg/m². This is related to large tile size and need for thick adhesive layer for reliable fixation. Use special adhesive for large-format tile.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for house?
faqItems.a: For house calculate area of each room separately. Use different adhesive types for different rooms. Sum results for total number of packages. Account that for large rooms better buy adhesive in bulk.

faqItems.q: What is white tile adhesive?
faqItems.a: White tile adhesive is used for light tile and mosaic to avoid dark adhesive showing through tile. Consumption is same as regular adhesive - 3-5 kg/m². Costs more than regular adhesive.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for heated floor?
faqItems.a: For heated floor use special elastic adhesive that withstands temperature variations. Consumption is 4-6 kg/m². Add reserve 15% for accounting temperature expansions.

faqItems.q: How long does tile adhesive dry?
faqItems.a: Tile adhesive drying time depends on type. Cement adhesive dries 24-48 hours, dispersion - 12-24 hours, epoxy - 6-12 hours. Account for drying time when planning work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for exterior work?
faqItems.a: For exterior work use frost-resistant adhesive for exterior application. Measure surface area. Use consumption rate 4-6 kg/m² with reserve 20% for accounting temperature and humidity variations.

faqItems.q: What is reinforced tile adhesive?
faqItems.a: Reinforced tile adhesive has increased strength and adhesion. Used for large-format tile and complex conditions. Consumption is 5-6 kg/m². Costs more than regular adhesive.

faqItems.q: How to calculate adhesive for renovation?
faqItems.a: For renovation measure floor or wall area that needs re-tiling. Use consumption rate depending on tile size. Add reserve 10-15% for fitting and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What consumption rate for tile 30×30 cm?
faqItems.a: For standard tile 30×30 cm consumption rate is 3-4 kg/m². This is average consumption for most types of cement and dispersion adhesive with proper installation.

seo.title: Putty Calculator Online - Calculate Putty for Walls | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online putty calculator for accurate calculation of putty quantity for wall leveling before painting or wallpapering. Accounts for room dimensions, number of layers, consumption rate and reserve.

overview.title: Putty Calculator Online
overview.content: Online putty calculator will help calculate required putty quantity for wall leveling before painting or wallpapering. Accounts for room dimensions, wall height, windows and doors area, number of layers, consumption rate and reserve for losses and fitting.
overview.additionalContent: Putty calculator uses accurate formulas for calculating material quantity accounting for putty type, surface condition, application method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various putty types: starter, finish, universal, gypsum, cement. Calculation formula: Putty Quantity = (Wall Area - Openings Area) × Consumption Rate (kg/m²) × Number of Layers × (1 + Reserve / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Putty Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of putty quantity calculation for various rooms and putty types:

example1.title: Example 1: Bedroom 4×3 meters
example1.description: Standard bedroom with ceiling height 2.7 m, starter and finish putty
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window: 1.2×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 1.2 kg/m²
Reserve: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Openings Area: 1.2×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 3.6 m²
Useful Area: 37.8 - 3.6 = 34.2 m²
Consumption per Layer: 34.2 × 1.2 = 41.04 kg
Consumption for 2 Layers: 41.04 × 2 = 82.08 kg
With Reserve: 82.08 × 1.1 = 90.29 kg
Packages (25 kg): 90.29 / 25 = 3.61 ≈ 4 packages
example1.note: Standard bedroom, recommended to take 4-5 packages with small reserve

example2.title: Example 2: Living Room 5×4 meters
example2.description: Large living room with ceiling height 2.7 m, universal putty
example2.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 pcs 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 1.3 kg/m²
Reserve: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (5 + 4) × 2.7 = 48.6 m²
Openings Area: 2×1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 6.3 m²
Useful Area: 48.6 - 6.3 = 42.3 m²
Consumption per Layer: 42.3 × 1.3 = 54.99 kg
Consumption for 2 Layers: 54.99 × 2 = 109.98 kg
With Reserve: 109.98 × 1.15 = 126.48 kg
Packages (25 kg): 126.48 / 25 = 5.06 ≈ 6 packages
example2.note: For large room increased reserve 15% is recommended

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3×2.5 meters
example3.description: Kitchen with ceiling height 2.5 m, cement putty for wet rooms
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window: 1.2×1.2 m
Door: 0.8×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 1.4 kg/m²
Reserve: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (3 + 2.5) × 2.5 = 27.5 m²
Openings Area: 1.2×1.2 + 0.8×2.0 = 3.04 m²
Useful Area: 27.5 - 3.04 = 24.46 m²
Consumption per Layer: 24.46 × 1.4 = 34.24 kg
Consumption for 2 Layers: 34.24 × 2 = 68.48 kg
With Reserve: 68.48 × 1.1 = 75.33 kg
Packages (25 kg): 75.33 / 25 = 3.01 ≈ 4 packages
example3.note: For kitchen moisture-resistant cement putty is recommended

example4.title: Example 4: Children's Room 4×3.5 meters
example4.description: Children's room with ceiling height 2.6 m, gypsum putty
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.6 m
Window: 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 1.2 kg/m²
Reserve: 10%
example4.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3.5) × 2.6 = 39.0 m²
Openings Area: 1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 4.05 m²
Useful Area: 39.0 - 4.05 = 34.95 m²
Consumption per Layer: 34.95 × 1.2 = 41.94 kg
Consumption for 2 Layers: 41.94 × 2 = 83.88 kg
With Reserve: 83.88 × 1.1 = 92.27 kg
Packages (25 kg): 92.27 / 25 = 3.69 ≈ 4 packages
example4.note: For children's room eco-friendly gypsum putty is recommended

example5.title: Example 5: Ceiling 6×5 meters
example5.description: Large ceiling with strong irregularities, starter and finish putty
example5.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m
Ceiling Area: 30 m²
Layers: 3
Consumption Rate: 1.5 kg/m²
Reserve: 15%
example5.calculation:
Useful Area: 30 m²
Consumption per Layer: 30 × 1.5 = 45 kg
Consumption for 3 Layers: 45 × 3 = 135 kg
With Reserve: 135 × 1.15 = 155.25 kg
Packages (25 kg): 155.25 / 25 = 6.21 ≈ 7 packages
example5.note: For strongly irregular ceilings more layers and increased consumption are required

example6.title: Example 6: Bathroom 2×1.5 meters
example6.description: Small bathroom with ceiling height 2.5 m, moisture-resistant putty
example6.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 1.3 kg/m²
Reserve: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (2 + 1.5) × 2.5 = 17.5 m²
Openings Area: 0.9×2.0 = 1.8 m²
Useful Area: 17.5 - 1.8 = 15.7 m²
Consumption per Layer: 15.7 × 1.3 = 20.41 kg
Consumption for 2 Layers: 20.41 × 2 = 40.82 kg
With Reserve: 40.82 × 1.1 = 44.9 kg
Packages (25 kg): 44.9 / 25 = 1.8 ≈ 2 packages
example6.note: For bathroom moisture-resistant putty is required

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty quantity?
faqItems.a: To calculate putty measure room wall length, width and height, subtract windows and doors area, multiply by consumption rate (usually 1-1.5 kg/m²), multiply by number of layers and add reserve 10-15%. Calculator will automatically perform all calculations.

faqItems.q: How much putty needed per 1 m²?
faqItems.a: Putty consumption is usually 1-1.5 kg/m² for starter putty and 0.8-1.2 kg/m² for finish putty per one layer. For strongly irregular surfaces consumption may be higher.

faqItems.q: How many putty layers are needed?
faqItems.a: Usually 2 layers are enough: one layer of starter putty and one layer of finish putty. For strongly irregular walls may require 3-4 layers of starter putty plus finish layer.

faqItems.q: What is difference between starter and finish putty?
faqItems.a: Starter putty is used for leveling significant irregularities (consumption 1.2-1.5 kg/m²). Finish putty is used for final leveling (consumption 0.8-1.2 kg/m²). Universal putty can be used both for start and finish.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for bedroom?
faqItems.a: For bedroom measure room dimensions, specify windows and doors area. Usually 2 layers are enough (starter + finish). Use consumption rate 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for ceiling?
faqItems.a: For ceiling measure ceiling area in square meters. For ceiling usually more putty is required due to application complexity. Use consumption rate 1.2-1.5 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 15%.

faqItems.q: What putty is better for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls recommended to use gypsum or universal putty for dry rooms. For wet rooms (kitchen, bathroom) use cement or polymer moisture-resistant putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen use moisture-resistant cement or polymer putty. Measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Use consumption rate 1.3-1.5 kg/m² per layer for wet rooms. Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much does putty package weigh?
faqItems.a: Standard putty package weighs 25 kg. Also exist packages of 5 kg, 10 kg and 50 kg. For large volumes better buy packages of 25 or 50 kg.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For bathroom use moisture-resistant cement or polymer putty. Measure wall area, subtract door area. Use consumption rate 1.3-1.5 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What is difference between gypsum and cement putty?
faqItems.a: Gypsum putty suits for dry rooms, easily sanded, consumption 1-1.3 kg/m². Cement putty is moisture-resistant, suits for wet rooms, consumption 1.3-1.5 kg/m². Quantity calculation for both types is same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for living room?
faqItems.a: For living room measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Usually 2 layers are enough (starter + finish). Use consumption rate 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: Should windows and doors be accounted for when calculating putty?
faqItems.a: Yes, definitely account for all windows and doors when calculating putty. Subtracting openings area from total wall area allows getting accurate useful area for treatment and avoid material overconsumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for children's room?
faqItems.a: For children's room measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Recommended to use eco-friendly gypsum putty. Use consumption rate 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What is universal putty?
faqItems.a: Universal putty can be used both for starter and finish layer. It is convenient for small works. Consumption is 1-1.3 kg/m² per layer. Quantity calculation is same as for regular putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for hallway?
faqItems.a: For hallway measure length and width, ceiling height. Account for all doors in hallway. Use consumption rate 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 10-15% for fitting.

faqItems.q: How much putty needed for 20 m² room?
faqItems.a: For room area 20 m² (approximately 4×5 m) with standard ceiling height 2.7 m need approximately 50-70 kg of putty (2-3 packages of 25 kg) for 2 layers accounting for reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for studio?
faqItems.a: For studio measure area of all walls. Account for all windows and doors. Choose putty type depending on zoning. For open spaces use universal putty. Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is polymer putty?
faqItems.a: Polymer putty is modern type of putty based on polymers. It is elastic, moisture-resistant, easily applied. Consumption is 1-1.3 kg/m² per layer. Quantity calculation is same as for regular putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for toilet?
faqItems.a: For toilet measure wall area. Subtract door area. Use moisture-resistant cement or polymer putty. Account for small room area. Use consumption rate 1.3 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What putty is better for painting?
faqItems.a: For painting recommended to use finish gypsum or universal putty. It creates smooth surface, consumption 0.8-1.2 kg/m² per layer. After putty definitely prime surface before painting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For apartment calculate area of each room separately. Use different putty types for different rooms (moisture-resistant for kitchen and bathroom, gypsum for living rooms). Sum results for total number of packages.

faqItems.q: Should putty be bought with reserve?
faqItems.a: Yes, definitely buy putty with reserve 10-15% for fitting, defects and possible errors during application. Reserve helps avoid situation when one package is missing and hard to find exact same in store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for entrance hall?
faqItems.a: For entrance hall measure wall area. Account for all doors. Use wear-resistant putty for high traffic. Use consumption rate 1.2 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 10-15% for fitting.

faqItems.q: What is latex putty?
faqItems.a: Latex putty is elastic polymer putty with latex addition. It is very elastic, moisture-resistant, easily applied. Consumption is 1-1.2 kg/m² per layer. Quantity calculation is same as for regular putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for house?
faqItems.a: For house calculate area of each room separately. Use different putty types for different rooms. Sum results for total number of packages. Account that for large rooms better buy putty in bulk.

faqItems.q: How long does putty dry?
faqItems.a: Putty drying time depends on type and layer thickness. Gypsum putty dries 24-48 hours, cement - 48-72 hours, polymer - 12-24 hours. Account for drying time when planning work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for strongly irregular walls?
faqItems.a: For strongly irregular walls increase number of layers to 3-4, use increased consumption rate 1.5-1.8 kg/m² per layer, add reserve 15-20% to regular calculation. Account for need of leveling significant irregularities.

faqItems.q: What is acrylic putty?
faqItems.a: Acrylic putty is universal polymer putty based on acrylic. It is elastic, moisture-resistant, suits for various surfaces. Consumption is 1-1.3 kg/m² per layer. Quantity calculation is same as for regular putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for renovation?
faqItems.a: For renovation measure wall or ceiling area that needs re-puttying. Use consumption rate depending on putty type. Add reserve 10-15% for fitting and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What consumption rate for starter layer?
faqItems.a: For starter layer consumption rate is 1.2-1.5 kg/m² depending on surface irregularity. For strongly irregular surfaces consumption may be higher - up to 1.8 kg/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for wallpaper?
faqItems.a: For preparing walls for wallpaper use starter and finish putty. Measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Use consumption rate 1.2 kg/m² per layer for 2 layers. Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What is finish putty?
faqItems.a: Finish putty is used for final surface leveling before painting or wallpapering. It creates smooth surface, consumption is 0.8-1.2 kg/m² per layer. Applied over starter putty.

faqItems.q: How to calculate putty for ceiling with suspended structure?
faqItems.a: For ceiling with suspended structure calculate ceiling area. Use consumption rate 1.2-1.5 kg/m² per layer. Add reserve 15% for complex shapes and fitting. Account for need of leveling base ceiling before installing suspended structure.

overview.title: Primer Calculator Online
overview.content: Online primer calculator will help calculate required primer quantity for wall surface preparation before painting or wallpapering. Accounts for room dimensions, wall height, windows and doors area, consumption rate and reserve for losses. Primer is applied in one layer.
overview.additionalContent: Primer calculator uses accurate formulas for calculating material quantity accounting for primer type, surface condition, application method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various primer types: acrylic, alkyd, deep-penetrating, universal. Calculation formula: Primer Quantity = (Wall Area - Openings Area) × Consumption Rate (L/m²) × (1 + Reserve / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Primer Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of primer quantity calculation for various rooms and primer types:

example1.title: Example 1: Bedroom 4×3 meters
example1.description: Standard bedroom with ceiling height 2.7 m, acrylic primer
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Window: 1.2×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption Rate: 0.1 L/m²
Reserve: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Openings Area: 1.2×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 3.6 m²
Useful Area: 37.8 - 3.6 = 34.2 m²
Primer Consumption: 34.2 × 0.1 = 3.42 L
With Reserve: 3.42 × 1.1 = 3.76 L
Packages (10 L): 3.76 / 10 = 0.38 ≈ 1 package
example1.note: Standard bedroom, recommended to take 1 package with small reserve

example2.title: Example 2: Living Room 5×4 meters
example2.description: Large living room with ceiling height 2.7 m, universal primer
example2.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 pcs 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (5 + 4) × 2.7 = 48.6 m²
Openings Area: 2×1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 6.3 m²
Useful Area: 48.6 - 6.3 = 42.3 m²
Primer Consumption: 42.3 × 0.12 = 5.08 L
With Reserve: 5.08 × 1.15 = 5.84 L
Packages (10 L): 5.84 / 10 = 0.58 ≈ 1 package
example2.note: For large room increased reserve 15% is recommended

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3×2.5 meters
example3.description: Kitchen with ceiling height 2.5 m, deep-penetrating primer
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Window: 1.2×1.2 m
Door: 0.8×2.0 m
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (3 + 2.5) × 2.5 = 27.5 m²
Openings Area: 1.2×1.2 + 0.8×2.0 = 3.04 m²
Useful Area: 27.5 - 3.04 = 24.46 m²
Primer Consumption: 24.46 × 0.12 = 2.94 L
With Reserve: 2.94 × 1.1 = 3.23 L
Packages (5 L): 3.23 / 5 = 0.65 ≈ 1 package
example3.note: For kitchen deep-penetrating primer is recommended

example4.title: Example 4: Children's Room 4×3.5 meters
example4.description: Children's room with ceiling height 2.6 m, acrylic primer
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3.5 m, Height: 2.6 m
Window: 1.5×1.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption Rate: 0.1 L/m²
Reserve: 10%
example4.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3.5) × 2.6 = 39.0 m²
Openings Area: 1.5×1.5 + 0.9×2.0 = 4.05 m²
Useful Area: 39.0 - 4.05 = 34.95 m²
Primer Consumption: 34.95 × 0.1 = 3.5 L
With Reserve: 3.5 × 1.1 = 3.85 L
Packages (5 L): 3.85 / 5 = 0.77 ≈ 1 package
example4.note: For children's room eco-friendly acrylic primer is recommended

example5.title: Example 5: Ceiling 6×5 meters
example5.description: Large ceiling, universal primer
example5.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m
Ceiling Area: 30 m²
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 15%
example5.calculation:
Useful Area: 30 m²
Primer Consumption: 30 × 0.12 = 3.6 L
With Reserve: 3.6 × 1.15 = 4.14 L
Packages (5 L): 4.14 / 5 = 0.83 ≈ 1 package
example5.note: For ceiling increased reserve 15% is recommended

example6.title: Example 6: Bathroom 2×1.5 meters
example6.description: Small bathroom with ceiling height 2.5 m, moisture-resistant primer
example6.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door: 0.9×2.0 m
Consumption Rate: 0.12 L/m²
Reserve: 10%
example6.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (2 + 1.5) × 2.5 = 17.5 m²
Openings Area: 0.9×2.0 = 1.8 m²
Useful Area: 17.5 - 1.8 = 15.7 m²
Primer Consumption: 15.7 × 0.12 = 1.88 L
With Reserve: 1.88 × 1.1 = 2.07 L
Packages (5 L): 2.07 / 5 = 0.41 ≈ 1 package
example6.note: For bathroom moisture-resistant primer is required

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer quantity?
faqItems.a: To calculate primer measure room wall length, width and height, subtract windows and doors area, multiply by consumption rate (usually 0.08-0.15 L/m²) and add reserve 10-15%. Calculator will automatically perform all calculations.

faqItems.q: How much primer needed per 1 m²?
faqItems.a: Primer consumption is usually 0.08-0.12 L/m² for smooth surfaces and 0.12-0.15 L/m² for porous surfaces. Primer is applied in one layer.

faqItems.q: How many primer layers are needed?
faqItems.a: Usually primer is applied in one layer. For strongly porous surfaces may require second layer. In such cases consumption increases twice.

faqItems.q: What is difference between acrylic and alkyd primer?
faqItems.a: Acrylic primer is universal, suitable for various surfaces (consumption 0.08-0.12 L/m²). Alkyd primer is used for wood and metal (consumption 0.1-0.15 L/m²). Quantity calculation for both types is same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for bedroom?
faqItems.a: For bedroom measure room dimensions, specify windows and doors area. Use acrylic or universal primer. Consumption rate 0.1 L/m². Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for ceiling?
faqItems.a: For ceiling measure ceiling area in square meters. For ceiling usually more primer is required due to application complexity. Use consumption rate 0.1-0.12 L/m². Add reserve 15%.

faqItems.q: What primer is better for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls recommended to use acrylic or universal primer for various surfaces. For wet rooms use moisture-resistant primer. For porous surfaces use deep-penetrating primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen use moisture-resistant acrylic or deep-penetrating primer. Measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Use consumption rate 0.12 L/m² for wet rooms. Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much does primer package weigh?
faqItems.a: Standard primer package volume 5 L weighs approximately 5-7 kg. Package 10 L weighs approximately 10-14 kg. Also exist packages of 1 L, 2.5 L and 20 L.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For bathroom use moisture-resistant deep-penetrating primer. Measure wall area, subtract door area. Use consumption rate 0.12-0.15 L/m² for wet rooms. Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What is deep-penetrating primer?
faqItems.a: Deep-penetrating primer penetrates deep into material pores, strengthens surface and improves adhesion. Consumption is 0.1-0.15 L/m². Used for loose and porous surfaces.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for living room?
faqItems.a: For living room measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Use acrylic or universal primer. Consumption rate 0.1 L/m². Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: Should windows and doors be accounted for when calculating primer?
faqItems.a: Yes, definitely account for all windows and doors when calculating primer. Subtracting openings area from total wall area allows getting accurate useful area for treatment and avoid material overconsumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for children's room?
faqItems.a: For children's room measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Recommended to use eco-friendly acrylic primer. Use consumption rate 0.1 L/m². Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What is universal primer?
faqItems.a: Universal primer suits for various surface types (concrete, plaster, drywall, wood). It is convenient for small works. Consumption is 0.1-0.12 L/m². Quantity calculation is same as for regular primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for hallway?
faqItems.a: For hallway measure length and width, ceiling height. Account for all doors in hallway. Use consumption rate 0.1-0.12 L/m². Add reserve 10-15% for fitting.

faqItems.q: How much primer needed for 20 m² room?
faqItems.a: For room area 20 m² (approximately 4×5 m) with standard ceiling height 2.7 m need approximately 3-4 L of primer (1 package 5 L) accounting for reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for studio?
faqItems.a: For studio measure area of all walls. Account for all windows and doors. Choose primer type depending on zoning. For open spaces use universal primer. Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: What is antiseptic primer?
faqItems.a: Antiseptic primer contains substances preventing mold and fungus appearance. Consumption is 0.12-0.15 L/m². Used for wet rooms and rooms with high humidity. Quantity calculation is same as for regular primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for toilet?
faqItems.a: For toilet measure wall area. Subtract door area. Use moisture-resistant antiseptic primer. Account for small room area. Use consumption rate 0.12 L/m². Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What primer is better for painting?
faqItems.a: For painting recommended to use acrylic or universal primer white color. It creates even base for paint, consumption 0.1-0.12 L/m². After primer wait for complete drying before painting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for entire apartment?
faqItems.a: For apartment calculate area of each room separately. Use different primer types for different rooms (moisture-resistant for kitchen and bathroom, regular for living rooms). Sum results for total number of packages.

faqItems.q: Should primer be bought with reserve?
faqItems.a: Yes, definitely buy primer with reserve 10-15% for fitting, defects and possible errors during application. Reserve helps avoid situation when small quantity is missing and hard to find exact same in store.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for entrance hall?
faqItems.a: For entrance hall measure wall area. Account for all doors. Use wear-resistant primer for high traffic. Use consumption rate 0.1-0.12 L/m². Add reserve 10-15% for fitting.

faqItems.q: What is adhesion primer?
faqItems.a: Adhesion primer improves material bonding with surface. Consumption is 0.1-0.15 L/m². Used for smooth surfaces before painting or wallpapering. Quantity calculation is same as for regular primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for house?
faqItems.a: For house calculate area of each room separately. Use different primer types for different rooms. Sum results for total number of packages. Account that for large rooms better buy primer in bulk.

faqItems.q: How long does primer dry?
faqItems.a: Primer drying time depends on type and conditions. Acrylic primer dries 4-6 hours, alkyd - 12-24 hours, deep-penetrating - 2-4 hours. Account for drying time when planning work.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for porous surfaces?
faqItems.a: For porous surfaces increase consumption rate to 0.12-0.15 L/m², add reserve 15-20% to regular calculation. Account for possibility of need for second layer for strongly porous surfaces.

faqItems.q: What is white primer?
faqItems.a: White primer is used before painting with light colors to avoid dark surface showing through. Consumption is same as regular primer - 0.1-0.12 L/m². Costs more than colorless primer.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for renovation?
faqItems.a: For renovation measure wall or ceiling area that needs priming. Use consumption rate depending on primer type. Add reserve 10-15% for fitting and possible defects.

faqItems.q: What consumption rate for walls?
faqItems.a: For walls consumption rate is 0.08-0.12 L/m² for smooth surfaces and 0.12-0.15 L/m² for porous surfaces. This is average consumption for most types of acrylic and universal primer with proper application.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for wallpaper?
faqItems.a: For preparing walls for wallpaper use acrylic or universal primer. Measure wall area, subtract windows and doors area. Use consumption rate 0.1-0.12 L/m². Add reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: What is colorless primer?
faqItems.a: Colorless primer is used for surface protection without changing its color. Consumption is same as regular primer - 0.1-0.12 L/m². Used before wallpapering or applying decorative coatings.

faqItems.q: How to calculate primer for drywall?
faqItems.a: For drywall use acrylic or universal primer. Measure wall area. Use consumption rate 0.1-0.12 L/m². Add reserve 10-15% for accounting drywall porosity.

overview.title: Plaster Calculator
overview.content: Online plaster calculator will help calculate required plaster quantity for wall finishing. Accounts for room dimensions, layer thickness, plaster type, number of layers and reserve for losses.
overview.additionalContent: Plaster calculator uses accurate formulas for calculating material quantity accounting for surface type, application method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various plaster types: cement, gypsum, decorative, lime. Calculation formula: Total Plaster Quantity = (Wall Area - Doors and Windows Area) × Consumption Rate (kg/m²) × Number of Layers × (1 + Reserve / 100). Consumption rate depends on layer thickness: usually 8-10 kg/m² per 1 mm layer thickness.

calculationExamples.title: Plaster Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of plaster quantity calculation for various rooms and plaster types:

example1.title: Example 1: Room 4×3 meters, Gypsum Plaster
example1.description: Standard room with ceiling height 2.7 m, gypsum plaster, layer thickness 10 mm
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m, Height: 2.7 m
Windows and Doors Area: 4.5 m²
Number of Layers: 1
Consumption Rate: 9 kg/m² (gypsum, 10 mm)
Reserve: 10%
example1.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 3) × 2.7 = 37.8 m²
Useful Area: 37.8 - 4.5 = 33.3 m²
Consumption per Layer: 33.3 × 9 = 299.7 kg
Total Consumption: 299.7 × 1 × 1.1 = 329.7 kg
example1.note: Gypsum plaster is easier to apply and dries faster, suitable for interior work

example2.title: Example 2: Large Living Room, Cement Plaster
example2.description: Spacious living room with large windows, cement plaster for facade, layer thickness 15 mm
example2.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 3 m
Windows and Doors Area: 12 m²
Number of Layers: 1
Consumption Rate: 17 kg/m² (cement, 15 mm)
Reserve: 15%
example2.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (6 + 5) × 3 = 66 m²
Useful Area: 66 - 12 = 54 m²
Consumption per Layer: 54 × 17 = 918 kg
Total Consumption: 918 × 1 × 1.15 = 1,055.7 kg
example2.note: Cement plaster is more durable, suitable for exterior work and wet rooms

example3.title: Example 3: Studio Apartment, Decorative Plaster
example3.description: Modern studio, decorative plaster for creating texture, thin layer
example3.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.5 m
Windows and Doors Area: 8 m²
Number of Layers: 1
Consumption Rate: 8 kg/m² (decorative, 5 mm)
Reserve: 10%
example3.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (5 + 4) × 2.5 = 45 m²
Useful Area: 45 - 8 = 37 m²
Consumption per Layer: 37 × 8 = 296 kg
Total Consumption: 296 × 1 × 1.1 = 325.6 kg
example3.note: Decorative plaster is applied in thin layer, creates unique surface texture

example4.title: Example 4: Hallway with Two Layers, Lime Plaster
example4.description: Narrow hallway, lime plaster in two layers for reliability
example4.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 1.5 m, Height: 2.7 m
Doors Area: 3 m²
Number of Layers: 2
Consumption Rate: 10 kg/m² (lime, 10 mm)
Reserve: 10%
example4.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (4 + 1.5) × 2.7 = 29.7 m²
Useful Area: 29.7 - 3 = 26.7 m²
Consumption per Layer: 26.7 × 10 = 267 kg
Total Consumption: 267 × 2 × 1.1 = 587.4 kg
example4.note: Lime plaster is breathable and eco-friendly, well suited for living rooms

example5.title: Example 5: Bathroom, Cement Plaster with Waterproofing
example5.description: Bathroom with high humidity, cement plaster for water protection
example5.input:
Length: 2.5 m, Width: 2 m, Height: 2.5 m
Door Area: 2 m²
Number of Layers: 1
Consumption Rate: 17 kg/m² (cement, 15 mm)
Reserve: 15%
example5.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (2.5 + 2) × 2.5 = 22.5 m²
Useful Area: 22.5 - 2 = 20.5 m²
Consumption per Layer: 20.5 × 17 = 348.5 kg
Total Consumption: 348.5 × 1 × 1.15 = 400.8 kg
example5.note: For bathrooms cement plaster is recommended due to high moisture resistance

example6.title: Example 6: Cottage, Facade Cement Plaster
example6.description: Exterior walls of cottage, cement plaster for weather protection, thick layer
example6.input:
Length: 10 m, Width: 8 m, Height: 3 m
Windows and Doors Area: 15 m²
Number of Layers: 1
Consumption Rate: 25 kg/m² (cement, 20 mm)
Reserve: 20%
example6.calculation:
Wall Area: 2 × (10 + 8) × 3 = 108 m²
Useful Area: 108 - 15 = 93 m²
Consumption per Layer: 93 × 25 = 2,325 kg
Total Consumption: 2,325 × 1 × 1.2 = 2,790 kg
example6.note: For facades thicker plaster layers are used for protection from moisture and temperature variations

tips.title: Plaster Work Tips
tips.content: For quality result when working with plaster follow our recommendations:

preparation.clean: Clean surface from dust, dirt and old coatings
preparation.prime: Coat surface with primer to improve adhesion
preparation.level: Install beacons for even plaster application

application.layers: If needed apply plaster in several layers with drying between layers
application.drying: Let plaster completely dry before further finishing

optimization.type: Choose plaster type depending on room (gypsum for dry, cement for wet)
optimization.tools: Use correct tools (trowel, rule, float) for quality application
optimization.reserve: Always add reserve 10-15% for losses and surface irregularities

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster quantity for walls?
faqItems.a: To calculate plaster measure room length and width, wall height. Calculate wall area: 2 × (Length + Width) × Height. Subtract windows and doors area. Multiply by consumption rate (usually 9-17 kg/m²) and number of layers. Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much plaster needed per 1 m² of wall?
faqItems.a: Plaster consumption depends on layer thickness: at thickness 10 mm consumption is 8-10 kg/m² for gypsum plaster and 15-17 kg/m² for cement. For each additional millimeter of thickness add approximately 0.8-1 kg/m² for gypsum and 1.5-1.7 kg/m² for cement.

faqItems.q: What is difference between gypsum and cement plaster?
faqItems.a: Gypsum plaster is lighter, dries faster (1-2 days), suitable for dry rooms. Cement plaster is stronger, moisture-resistant, dries longer (5-7 days), used for wet rooms and facades. Cement plaster consumption is higher due to greater density.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for facade?
faqItems.a: For facade use cement plaster with consumption rate 17-25 kg/m² depending on layer thickness (usually 15-20 mm). Account that for facades larger reserve (15-20%) is required due to wind, rain and losses when working at height.

faqItems.q: How much plaster needed for 20 m² room?
faqItems.a: For room 20 m² (for example, 5×4 m) with wall height 2.7 m wall area will be approximately 48.6 m². With consumption rate 9 kg/m² (gypsum, 10 mm) and reserve 10% need: 48.6 × 9 × 1.1 = 481 kg (16 bags of 30 kg).

faqItems.q: How to calculate decorative plaster?
faqItems.a: Decorative plaster is applied in thin layer (3-5 mm), so consumption is less: 6-10 kg/m². For calculation multiply wall area by consumption rate accounting for texture (relief textures require more material). Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: Can gypsum plaster be used in wet rooms?
faqItems.a: No, gypsum plaster is not suitable for wet rooms (bathroom, kitchen, basement). In wet rooms use cement plaster with waterproofing additives. Gypsum plaster absorbs moisture and deteriorates.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster accounting for beacons?
faqItems.a: Beacons do not affect plaster consumption, they are needed only for leveling. Consumption is calculated by same formula: wall area × consumption rate. Beacons are installed for layer thickness control and not accounted in material calculation.

faqItems.q: How long does plaster dry before painting?
faqItems.a: Gypsum plaster dries 1-2 days, cement - 5-7 days. Complete drying before painting is mandatory, otherwise paint may peel off. Drying time depends on layer thickness, temperature and air humidity.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for ceiling?
faqItems.a: For ceiling use ceiling area (Length × Width). Consumption rate is same as for walls: 9-17 kg/m² depending on type. Account that ceiling work may increase losses by 5-10%, add larger reserve.

faqItems.q: What is rough and finish plaster?
faqItems.a: Rough plaster (scratch and brown coat) - base layer for leveling, consumption 15-20 kg/m². Finish plaster (skim coat) - thin layer 2-5 mm for final finishing, consumption 3-5 kg/m². Usually used together.

faqItems.q: How to calculate warm plaster?
faqItems.a: Warm plaster contains insulating additives (perlite, vermiculite), consumption 10-12 kg/m² at thickness 10 mm. Calculated similarly to regular plaster: area × consumption rate × number of layers × (1 + reserve).

faqItems.q: How many m² will 30 kg bag of plaster cover?
faqItems.a: Bag 30 kg of gypsum plaster with consumption rate 9 kg/m² (layer 10 mm) will cover 3.3 m². Bag of cement plaster with rate 17 kg/m² (layer 15 mm) will cover 1.8 m². Calculation: 30 / consumption_rate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for room with columns?
faqItems.a: For columns calculate area as perimeter × height and add to total wall area. Use standard consumption rate. Columns may have complex shape, add reserve 15-20% for processing corners and curved surfaces.

faqItems.q: Is primer needed before plaster?
faqItems.a: Yes, primer is mandatory before plaster. It improves plaster adhesion to surface, prevents water absorption and increases coating strength. Primer consumption: 0.1-0.15 L/m², accounted separately from plaster.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for room with bay window?
faqItems.a: For bay window measure area of all bay window walls and add to total area. Bay window adds additional area. Use standard consumption rate. Account that bay window corners may require more material, add reserve 15%.

faqItems.q: Can plaster be applied in one layer?
faqItems.a: For thin layers (up to 10 mm) can be applied in one layer. For thick layers (15-20 mm) recommended to apply in two layers to prevent cracking. First layer - rough, second - finish.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for concrete walls?
faqItems.a: Concrete walls require preliminary preparation (primer, scoring for adhesion). Plaster consumption is standard: 9-17 kg/m² depending on type. Concrete may be uneven, add reserve 15% for leveling.

faqItems.q: How much plaster needed for two-room apartment?
faqItems.a: For two-room apartment area 50-60 m² with ceiling height 2.7 m total wall area will be approximately 120-150 m². With consumption rate 9 kg/m² need: 120 × 9 × 1.1 = 1,188 kg (40 bags of 30 kg) for all walls.

faqItems.q: How to calculate mechanical plaster?
faqItems.a: Mechanical plaster is applied by machine, consumption is same as manual application: 9-17 kg/m². Advantage of mechanical plaster - speed and layer uniformity, which reduces losses. Reserve can be reduced to 5-10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster on mesh?
faqItems.a: Plaster on mesh is used for coating reinforcement. Consumption increases by 10-15% due to mesh cell filling. Use consumption rate 10-19 kg/m² instead of standard 9-17 kg/m² when working on mesh.

faqItems.q: How long does gypsum plaster dry before wallpapering?
faqItems.a: Gypsum plaster dries 1-2 days, but before wallpapering need to wait complete drying - 3-5 days depending on layer thickness. Wet plaster under wallpaper may lead to mold appearance.

faqItems.q: How to calculate lime plaster?
faqItems.a: Lime plaster has consumption 8-12 kg/m² at layer thickness 10 mm. It is lighter than cement, eco-friendly, breathable. Calculated similarly: area × consumption rate × number of layers × (1 + reserve). Suitable for living rooms.

faqItems.q: Can plastering be done in winter?
faqItems.a: Plaster can be applied in winter only at temperature above +5°C and using anti-freeze additives for cement plaster. Gypsum plaster is not used at negative temperatures. In winter drying time increases.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for room with niches?
faqItems.a: For room with niches measure wall area of niches and add to total area. Niches increase area for plastering. Use standard consumption rate. Corners and complex shapes of niches may require more material, add reserve 15%.

faqItems.q: How much does plastering cost per m²?
faqItems.a: Plastering work cost depends on surface type and region. Average: rough plaster $5-10/m², finish plaster $7-15/m². Decorative plaster is more expensive: $15-30/m². Prices shown without materials.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for balcony?
faqItems.a: For balcony use cement or facade plaster with consumption rate 17-25 kg/m². Measure area of all balcony walls, including railings. Account that balconies are subject to temperature variations, use reserve 15-20%.

faqItems.q: What is ready-made plaster?
faqItems.a: Ready-made plaster is sold as ready paste in buckets. Ready-made plaster consumption is indicated on package, usually 1.5-2.5 kg/m² at layer thickness 1 mm. It is more convenient to use, but more expensive than dry mixes.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for textured ceilings?
faqItems.a: For textured ceilings consumption increases by 20-30% due to relief. Use consumption rate 11-22 kg/m² instead of standard 9-17 kg/m² depending on texture depth. Textured surfaces require more material for filling.

faqItems.q: How much plaster needed for 100 m² house?
faqItems.a: For house 100 m² with ceiling height 3 m total wall area will be approximately 360 m² (for square house 10×10 m). With consumption rate 9 kg/m² and reserve 10% need: 360 × 9 × 1.1 = 3,564 kg (119 bags of 30 kg) for all walls.

faqItems.q: How to calculate plaster for clay walls?
faqItems.a: Clay walls require special preparation before plastering (reinforcement, primer). Consumption is standard: 9-17 kg/m². Clay walls may be uneven, add reserve 15-20%. Recommended to use lime or cement plaster.
