overview.title: Foundation Calculator
overview.content: Online foundation calculator will help calculate required material quantity for foundation construction. Supports calculation of strip, slab and column foundations. Accounts for concrete volume, rebar quantity, formwork area and all necessary materials.
overview.additionalContent: Foundation calculator uses accurate formulas for calculating concrete volume, rebar weight and formwork area. Suitable for calculating various foundation types: strip (for houses), slab (for uniform load), column (for light structures). Calculation formula: Concrete Volume = Area × Height (each foundation type has its own formula). Rebar is calculated based on concrete volume and reinforcement density.

calculationExamples.title: Foundation Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of material calculation for various foundation types:

example1.title: Example 1: Strip Foundation for 6×8 m House
example1.description: Strip foundation for one-story house, depth 1.5 m
example1.input:
Type: Strip
Length: 8 m, Width: 6 m, Height: 1.5 m
Wall Thickness: 0.4 m
Concrete Grade: M200
Rebar: 12 mm, spacing 20 cm, 2 layers
Reserve: 10%
example1.result: Concrete: 16.37 m³, Cement: 92 bags, Rebar: 1,640 kg
example1.note: Strip foundation is most common for private houses, provides reliable support

example2.title: Example 2: Slab Foundation for 10×10 m House
example2.description: Monolithic slab for two-story house, thickness 30 cm
example2.input:
Type: Slab
Length: 10 m, Width: 10 m, Thickness: 0.3 m
Concrete Grade: M250
Rebar: 14 mm, spacing 20 cm, 2 layers
Reserve: 10%
example2.calculation:
Volume: 10 × 10 × 0.3 = 30 m³
With Reserve: 30 × 1.1 = 33 m³
Cement: 33 × 330 = 10,890 kg (218 bags)
Sand: 33 × 720 = 23,760 kg
Gravel: 33 × 1250 = 41,250 kg
Rebar: ~3,300 kg (275 bars of 12 m)
example2.result: Concrete: 33 m³, Cement: 218 bags, Rebar: 3,300 kg
example2.note: Slab foundation distributes load evenly, suitable for weak soils

example3.title: Example 3: Column Foundation for 4×4 m Bathhouse
example3.description: Column foundation for bathhouse, 9 columns
example3.input:
Type: Column
Quantity: 9 columns
Column Size: 0.4×0.4 m, Height: 1.2 m
Concrete Grade: M200
Rebar: 10 mm, spacing 15 cm, 1 layer
Reserve: 10%
example3.calculation:
Volume of one column: 0.4 × 0.4 × 1.2 = 0.192 m³
Total Volume: 0.192 × 9 = 1.728 m³
With Reserve: 1.728 × 1.1 = 1.9 m³
Cement: 1.9 × 280 = 532 kg (11 bags)
Sand: 1.9 × 730 = 1,387 kg
Gravel: 1.9 × 1250 = 2,375 kg
Rebar: ~190 kg (16 bars of 12 m)
example3.result: Concrete: 1.9 m³, Cement: 11 bags, Rebar: 190 kg
example3.note: Column foundation is economical for light structures, quickly built

example4.title: Example 4: Shallow Strip Foundation
example4.description: Strip foundation for one-story frame house
example4.input:
Type: Strip
Length: 8 m, Width: 6 m, Height: 0.6 m (shallow)
Wall Thickness: 0.3 m
Concrete Grade: M200
Rebar: 10 mm, spacing 25 cm, 2 layers
Reserve: 10%
example4.result: Concrete: 2.42 m³, Cement: 14 bags, Rebar: 242 kg
example4.note: Shallow foundation suitable for stable soils and light structures

example5.title: Example 5: Insulated Slab Foundation
example5.description: Insulated slab for energy-efficient house
example5.input:
Type: Slab
Length: 12 m, Width: 10 m, Thickness: 0.25 m
Concrete Grade: M300
Rebar: 16 mm, spacing 15 cm, 2 layers
Reserve: 15%
example5.result: Concrete: 34.5 m³, Cement: 263 bags, Rebar: 3,450 kg
example5.note: Insulated slab foundation provides energy efficiency and comfort in house

example6.title: Example 6: Column Foundation for Terrace
example6.description: Column foundation for open terrace
example6.input:
Type: Column
Quantity: 6 columns
Column Size: 0.3×0.3 m, Height: 0.8 m
Concrete Grade: M200
Rebar: 8 mm, spacing 20 cm, 1 layer
Reserve: 10%
example6.calculation:
Volume of one column: 0.3 × 0.3 × 0.8 = 0.072 m³
Total Volume: 0.072 × 6 = 0.432 m³
With Reserve: 0.432 × 1.1 = 0.475 m³
Cement: 0.475 × 280 = 133 kg (3 bags)
Sand: 0.475 × 730 = 346.75 kg
Gravel: 0.475 × 1250 = 593.75 kg
Rebar: ~47.5 kg (4 bars of 12 m)
example6.result: Concrete: 0.475 m³, Cement: 3 bags, Rebar: 47.5 kg
example6.note: Column foundation is ideal for open areas and light superstructures

calculation.title: How Foundation Materials Are Calculated
calculation.content: Foundation material calculation includes several steps depending on foundation type, concrete grade and reinforcement parameters.
calculation.strip: Strip: V = (L×W×H) - ((L-2t)×(W-2t)×H), where L - length, W - width, H - height, t - wall thickness
calculation.slab: Slab: V = L×W×T, where L - length, W - width, T - slab thickness
calculation.columnar: Column: V = N×L×W×H, where N - number of columns, L×W×H - one column dimensions
calculation.materials: Materials: Cement = V×Cement_rate(grade), Sand = V×Sand_rate(grade), Gravel = V×Gravel_rate(grade)

advantages.title: Calculator Usage Advantages
advantages.content: Using foundation calculator provides many advantages when planning construction.

accuracy.title: Calculation Accuracy
accuracy.description: Calculator accounts for all parameters: foundation type, dimensions, concrete grade, reinforcement parameters. This guarantees accurate calculation without overpayment or material shortage.

savings.title: Cost Savings
savings.description: Correct calculation allows buying exact material quantity without excess. Savings can be 10-15% of foundation material cost.

planning.title: Purchase Planning
planning.description: Knowing exact concrete, rebar and formwork quantity, can plan material purchases in advance and avoid work downtime due to material shortage.

tips.title: Foundation Construction Tips
tips.content: For quality foundation follow our recommendations:

preparation.soil: Conduct geological soil survey before design
preparation.level: Level site and prepare sand and gravel cushion
preparation.drainage: Provide drainage to divert water from foundation

reinforcement.diameter: Choose rebar diameter depending on load (10-16 mm for private houses)
reinforcement.spacing: Follow rebar spacing 15-25 cm for optimal reinforcement
reinforcement.layers: Use minimum 2 rebar layers for strip and slab foundations

concreting.grade: Choose concrete grade depending on load (M200 for light, M250-M300 for heavy structures)
concreting.mixing: Mix concrete in correct proportions or use ready-made
concreting.curing: Provide correct concrete curing (watering, covering) for 28 days

faqItems.q: How to calculate concrete quantity for foundation?
faqItems.a: To calculate concrete determine foundation volume. For strip: volume = (length×width×height) - (internal volume). For slab: volume = length×width×thickness. For column: volume = quantity×column size. Then multiply by concrete grade and add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How much concrete needed for 10×10 m foundation?
faqItems.a: For strip foundation 10×10 m with depth 1.5 m and wall thickness 0.4 m volume will be approximately 22 m³. Accounting for reserve 10% need 24.2 m³ concrete. For slab foundation thickness 30 cm need 30 m³ (10×10×0.3) plus reserve.

faqItems.q: How to calculate rebar for foundation?
faqItems.a: Rebar is calculated based on concrete volume and reinforcement density. Usually use 100-150 kg rebar per 1 m³ concrete. For strip foundation use rebar diameter 10-14 mm with spacing 15-25 cm in 2 layers (top and bottom).

faqItems.q: What concrete grade to use for foundation?
faqItems.a: For private houses usually use M200 (light structures) or M250 (two-story houses). For heavy structures and multi-story houses use M300. M200 contains 280 kg cement per m³, M250 - 330 kg, M300 - 380 kg.

faqItems.q: How to calculate strip foundation?
faqItems.a: For strip foundation measure house perimeter and multiply by foundation width and depth. Subtract internal volume. Example: house 8×10 m, perimeter 36 m, width 0.4 m, depth 1.5 m → volume = 36×0.4×1.5 = 21.6 m³. Subtract internal wall volume.

faqItems.q: How to calculate slab foundation?
faqItems.a: For slab foundation volume = length × width × thickness. Slab thickness usually 20-40 cm depending on load. Example: house 10×12 m, thickness 30 cm → volume = 10×12×0.3 = 36 m³. Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate column foundation?
faqItems.a: For column foundation calculate volume of one column (length×width×height) and multiply by number of columns. Usually columns are installed at corners and every 1.5-2 m. Example: 9 columns 0.4×0.4×1.2 m → volume = 9×0.192 = 1.73 m³.

faqItems.q: How much rebar needed for foundation?
faqItems.a: Rebar quantity depends on foundation type and load. For strip foundation usually 100-150 kg rebar per 1 m³ concrete. For slab foundation - 50-80 kg/m³. For column - 80-120 kg/m³. Rebar diameter: 10-14 mm for private houses.

faqItems.q: What foundation depth for house?
faqItems.a: Foundation depth depends on soil type and freezing depth. For strip foundation usually 1.5-2 m (20 cm below freezing depth). For slab foundation depth depends on slab thickness (20-40 cm). For column - 1-1.5 m.

faqItems.q: How to calculate formwork for foundation?
faqItems.a: Formwork area = foundation perimeter × height × 2 (internal and external side). For strip foundation perimeter = 2×(length+width). For slab formwork only along perimeter. Example: house 8×10 m, height 1.5 m → perimeter 36 m, formwork area = 36×1.5×2 = 108 m².

faqItems.q: What is shallow foundation?
faqItems.a: Shallow foundation has depth 40-70 cm (above freezing depth). Suitable for stable soils and light structures (frame houses, bathhouses). Requires less concrete and rebar, built faster, but less stable on heaving soils.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for bathhouse?
faqItems.a: For bathhouse usually use column or shallow strip foundation. Column: 6-9 columns size 0.3×0.3 m, depth 0.8-1 m. Shallow strip: depth 0.5-0.7 m, width 0.3 m. Concrete volume for bathhouse 4×4 m will be 1-2 m³.

faqItems.q: How much does foundation cost for 100 m² house?
faqItems.a: Foundation cost depends on type and region. Strip foundation for 100 m² house: concrete volume 20-25 m³ × $40-50/m³ = $800-1,250. Rebar: 2-3 tons × $500/ton = $1,000-1,500. Work: $15-25/m³. Total: $3,000-5,000.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for garage?
faqItems.a: For garage usually use strip or slab foundation. Strip: perimeter × width × depth (usually 0.5-0.7 m). Slab: garage area × thickness (15-20 cm). For garage 6×4 m strip foundation will require 2-3 m³ concrete, slab - 4.8-6.4 m³.

faqItems.q: Is rebar needed in foundation?
faqItems.a: Yes, rebar is mandatory for all foundation types. It provides strength and prevents cracking. Without rebar foundation may crack at soil settlement or load. Minimum reinforcement: diameter 10 mm, spacing 20-25 cm, minimum 2 layers (top and bottom).

faqItems.q: How to calculate cushion under foundation?
faqItems.a: Cushion under foundation consists of sand (20-30 cm) and gravel (10-15 cm). Cushion area = foundation area. Sand volume = area × 0.25 m. Gravel volume = area × 0.15 m. Example: foundation 8×10 m → sand 20 m³, gravel 12 m³.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for two-story house?
faqItems.a: For two-story house stronger foundation is needed. Use deep strip (depth 1.5-2 m) or slab (thickness 30-40 cm). Concrete grade M250-M300. Rebar diameter 12-16 mm. Concrete volume for house 10×12 m will be 25-35 m³ depending on foundation type.

faqItems.q: How long does foundation cure?
faqItems.a: Foundation gains strength 28 days. First 3 days constant humidity is needed (watering 2-3 times per day). After 7 days can remove formwork. After 14 days can start wall masonry. Full strength achieved after 28 days.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation on slope?
faqItems.a: For slope usually use stepped strip foundation or pile grillage. Calculate each step separately. Volume = sum of all step volumes. Rebar calculated by total volume. Account for need of drainage and slope reinforcement.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation waterproofing?
faqItems.a: Waterproofing area = area of foundation vertical surfaces. For strip: perimeter × height. For slab: perimeter × thickness + base area. Roll waterproofing consumption: 1.1-1.2 m² per 1 m² surface (accounting for overlap).

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation insulation?
faqItems.a: Insulation area = area of foundation vertical surfaces. For strip: perimeter × height. Use extruded polystyrene thickness 5-10 cm. Consumption: foundation area × insulation thickness. Example: perimeter 36 m, height 1.5 m → area 54 m², insulation volume 10 cm = 5.4 m³.

faqItems.q: Can foundation be poured in winter?
faqItems.a: Foundation pouring in winter is possible at temperature above -5°C using anti-freeze additives and insulation. At temperature below -5°C requires concrete heating and formwork insulation. Recommended to pour foundation in warm season for better quality.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for frame house?
faqItems.a: For frame house shallow strip or column foundation is suitable. Strip: depth 0.5-0.7 m, width 0.3 m. Column: columns 0.3×0.3 m every 1.5-2 m. Concrete volume for house 6×8 m will be 2-4 m³ for strip or 1-2 m³ for column.

faqItems.q: How much cement needed for foundation?
faqItems.a: Cement quantity depends on concrete grade. M200: 280 kg/m³, M250: 330 kg/m³, M300: 380 kg/m³. Example: foundation 20 m³ concrete M200 requires 20×280 = 5,600 kg cement = 112 bags of 50 kg. Accounting for reserve 10% need 123 bags.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for shed?
faqItems.a: For shed usually use column or shallow strip foundation. Column: 4-6 columns size 0.3×0.3 m, depth 0.5-0.7 m. Concrete volume for shed 4×3 m will be 0.5-1 m³. Use concrete grade M200.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation drainage?
faqItems.a: Drainage calculated along foundation perimeter. Drain pipe length = foundation perimeter + 10% for turns. Pipe diameter 110 mm. Distance from foundation 0.5-1 m. Installation depth 0.3-0.5 m below foundation base. Example: perimeter 36 m → pipe 40 m.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for extension?
faqItems.a: For extension usually use same foundation type as main house. Depth should be same. Connection with main foundation through expansion joint. Concrete volume calculated similarly to main foundation. Example: extension 4×6 m, strip foundation → volume 2-3 m³.

faqItems.q: How much does formwork cost for foundation?
faqItems.a: Formwork cost depends on material and region. Wood formwork: $5-10/m². Metal formwork (rental): $3-5/m² per month. For foundation 36 m perimeter and height 1.5 m formwork area 108 m² → cost $540-1,080 (wood) or rental $324-540/month.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for timber house?
faqItems.a: For timber house shallow strip or column foundation is suitable. Strip: depth 0.7-1 m, width 0.3-0.4 m. Column: columns 0.4×0.4 m every 1.5-2 m. Concrete volume for house 8×10 m will be 5-8 m³ for strip or 2-3 m³ for column.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for aerated concrete house?
faqItems.a: For aerated concrete house use strip foundation (depth 1.5-2 m) or slab (thickness 30-40 cm). Foundation width should be 10 cm more than wall thickness. Concrete volume for house 10×12 m will be 20-30 m³ for strip or 36-48 m³ for slab. Concrete grade M250-M300.

faqItems.q: How much sand needed for foundation?
faqItems.a: Sand needed for cushion under foundation (20-30 cm) and for concrete. Cushion: foundation area × 0.25 m. Concrete: concrete volume × sand rate (730 kg/m³ for M200). Example: foundation 8×10 m, cushion 20 m³ sand, concrete 20 m³ → 20×730 = 14,600 kg sand for concrete. Total: 20 m³ + 14.6 t = 34.6 t sand.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for cottage?
faqItems.a: For cottage usually use deep strip or slab foundation. Strip: depth 1.5-2 m (below freezing), width 0.4-0.5 m. Concrete volume for cottage 12×15 m will be 30-40 m³. Concrete grade M250-M300. Rebar 12-16 mm, spacing 15-20 cm.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for country house?
faqItems.a: For country house column or shallow strip foundation is suitable. Column: columns 0.3×0.3 m every 1.5-2 m, depth 0.8-1 m. Shallow strip: depth 0.5-0.7 m, width 0.3 m. Concrete volume for country house 6×8 m will be 1-3 m³ depending on type.

faqItems.q: Is rebar needed in column foundation?
faqItems.a: Yes, rebar is mandatory in column foundation too. It provides column strength and prevents destruction. Usually use 4-6 bars diameter 10-12 mm, tied with stirrups. For column 0.4×0.4×1.2 m need 4.8-7.2 m rebar (4-6 bars of 1.2 m) plus stirrups.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for timber bathhouse?
faqItems.a: For timber bathhouse use column or shallow strip foundation. Column: 6-9 columns 0.4×0.4 m, depth 0.8-1 m. Strip: depth 0.6-0.8 m, width 0.3 m. Concrete volume for bathhouse 4×5 m will be 1-2 m³. Concrete grade M200.

faqItems.q: How much does it cost to pour foundation yourself?
faqItems.a: When pouring yourself material cost: concrete M200 20 m³ × $35/m³ = $700. Rebar 2 t × $500/ton = $1,000. Formwork (wood) 108 m² × $6/m² = $648. Sand, gravel: $300. Total: $2,648. DIY work saves $1,500-2,000.

faqItems.q: How to calculate foundation for house on slope?
faqItems.a: For slope use stepped strip foundation or pile grillage. Calculate each step separately. Volume = sum of all step volumes. Rebar calculated by total volume. Account for need of drainage and slope reinforcement. Example: 3 steps of 5 m³ each = 15 m³ concrete.

overview.title: Wall Area Calculator
overview.content: Online wall area calculator will help accurately calculate wall area for finishing. Accounts for room dimensions, ceiling height, windows and doors area, as well as reserve for losses. Suitable for calculating area for painting, wallpaper, plaster, tile and other finishing materials.
overview.additionalContent: Wall area calculator uses accurate formulas for calculating perimeter and area of all walls accounting for openings. Calculation formula: Perimeter = 2 × (Length + Width), Total Wall Area = Perimeter × Height, Useful Area = Total Area - Openings Area, Area with Reserve = Useful Area × (1 + Reserve / 100). For non-standard rooms supports selection of wall count (2, 3 or 4).

calculationExamples.title: Wall Area Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of wall area calculation for various rooms:

example1.title: Example 1: Standard Bedroom 4×5 m
example1.description: Rectangular bedroom with ceiling height 2.7 m, one window and one door
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 5 m
Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2.5 m²
Doors: 2 m²
Number of Walls: 4
Reserve: 10%
example1.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (4 + 5) = 18 m
Total Area: 18 × 2.7 = 48.6 m²
Openings: 2.5 + 2 = 4.5 m²
Useful Area: 48.6 - 4.5 = 44.1 m²
Reserve: 44.1 × 0.1 = 4.41 m²
Area with Reserve: 44.1 + 4.41 = 48.51 m²
example1.note: For standard bedroom usually requires 48-50 m² material for finishing accounting for reserve

example2.title: Example 2: Living Room 6×8 m with Large Windows
example2.description: Spacious living room with panoramic windows, height 3 m
example2.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 8 m
Height: 3 m
Windows: 12 m² (panoramic glazing)
Doors: 3 m²
Number of Walls: 4
Reserve: 15%
example2.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (6 + 8) = 28 m
Total Area: 28 × 3 = 84 m²
Openings: 12 + 3 = 15 m²
Useful Area: 84 - 15 = 69 m²
Reserve: 69 × 0.15 = 10.35 m²
Area with Reserve: 69 + 10.35 = 79.35 m²
example2.note: Large windows significantly reduce wall area, less material needed for finishing

example3.title: Example 3: Kitchen 3×4 m, Corner Room
example3.description: Corner kitchen with 3 walls, standard height
example3.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 4 m
Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 2 m²
Doors: 0 m² (arch)
Number of Walls: 3
Reserve: 10%
example3.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (3 + 4) = 14 m (approximately)
Total Area: ~35 m² (for 3 walls)
Openings: 2 m²
Useful Area: 35 - 2 = 33 m²
Reserve: 33 × 0.1 = 3.3 m²
Area with Reserve: 33 + 3.3 = 36.3 m²
example3.note: Corner rooms have fewer walls, which saves finishing materials

example4.title: Example 4: Bathroom 2.5×2 m
example4.description: Small bathroom with minimal openings
example4.input:
Length: 2.5 m, Width: 2 m
Height: 2.5 m
Windows: 0 m² (no windows)
Doors: 2 m²
Number of Walls: 4
Reserve: 15%
example4.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (2.5 + 2) = 9 m
Total Area: 9 × 2.5 = 22.5 m²
Openings: 2 m²
Useful Area: 22.5 - 2 = 20.5 m²
Reserve: 20.5 × 0.15 = 3.075 m²
Area with Reserve: 20.5 + 3.075 = 23.575 m²
example4.note: For bathroom reserve 15% is recommended due to complex conditions and need for precise tile cutting

example5.title: Example 5: Long Hallway 1.5×10 m
example5.description: Long hallway with two parallel walls
example5.input:
Length: 10 m, Width: 1.5 m
Height: 2.7 m
Windows: 0 m²
Doors: 5 m² (several doors)
Number of Walls: 2
Reserve: 10%
example5.calculation:
Perimeter: ~20 m (for 2 walls)
Total Area: ~54 m²
Openings: 5 m²
Useful Area: 54 - 5 = 49 m²
Reserve: 49 × 0.1 = 4.9 m²
Area with Reserve: 49 + 4.9 = 53.9 m²
example5.note: Hallways usually have only 2 walls (opposite), which simplifies calculation

example6.title: Example 6: Office Room 8×10 m
example6.description: Large office with many windows and doors, height 3 m
example6.input:
Length: 8 m, Width: 10 m
Height: 3 m
Windows: 20 m² (many windows)
Doors: 6 m²
Number of Walls: 4
Reserve: 10%
example6.calculation:
Perimeter: 2 × (8 + 10) = 36 m
Total Area: 36 × 3 = 108 m²
Openings: 20 + 6 = 26 m²
Useful Area: 108 - 26 = 82 m²
Reserve: 82 × 0.1 = 8.2 m²
Area with Reserve: 82 + 8.2 = 90.2 m²
example6.note: Office rooms usually have many openings, which significantly reduces area for finishing

calculation.title: How Wall Area Is Calculated
calculation.content: Wall area calculation includes several steps to get accurate result accounting for all openings and reserve.
calculation.usefulArea: Useful Area = Total Area - Windows Area - Doors Area
calculation.areaWithReserve: Area with Reserve = Useful Area × (1 + Reserve / 100)

advantages.title: Calculator Usage Advantages
advantages.content: Using wall area calculator provides many advantages when planning finishing work.

accuracy.title: Calculation Accuracy
accuracy.description: Calculator accounts for all parameters: room dimensions, wall height, openings area. This guarantees accurate calculation without overpayment or material shortage.

planning.title: Purchase Planning
planning.description: Knowing exact wall area, can plan material purchases in advance and avoid work downtime due to material shortage.

savings.title: Cost Savings
savings.description: Correct calculation allows buying exact material quantity without excess. Savings can be 10-15% of material cost.

tips.title: Wall Area Calculation Tips
tips.content: For accurate result when calculating wall area follow our recommendations:

measurements.accurate: Measure room dimensions accurately, using tape measure on floor and walls
measurements.height: Measure wall height in several places (may differ up to 5-10 cm)
measurements.multiple: For accuracy make several measurements of each wall

openings.all: Account for all openings: windows, doors, arches, niches
openings.measure: Measure openings area accurately: width × height
openings.account: For panels and tile account that openings may reduce waste quantity

reserve.standard: For painting and wallpaper 10% reserve is enough
reserve.complex: For complex surfaces and patterns add 15-20% reserve
reserve.material: For tile and panels reserve depends on material size and installation method

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for painting?
faqItems.a: Measure room length and width, wall height. Calculate perimeter: 2 × (Length + Width). Multiply perimeter by height. Subtract windows and doors area. Add reserve 10%. Example: room 4×5 m, height 2.7 m → perimeter 18 m, area 48.6 m², minus windows and doors 4.5 m² = 44.1 m², with reserve 48.51 m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Calculation similar to painting: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. For wallpaper important to account for pattern repeat (rapport) and application method. Reserve for patterned wallpaper: 15-20%, plain: 10%. Measure height from floor to ceiling in several places and use maximum value.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for tile?
faqItems.a: Area calculation: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. For tile reserve depends on tile size and installation method: straight - 10%, diagonal - 15%, complex patterns - 20%. Account for cutting in corners and around openings. For bathroom reserve 15-20% is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area with windows and doors?
faqItems.a: Calculate total wall area: perimeter × height. Measure area of each window (width × height) and each door. Sum areas of all openings. Subtract from total area. Formula: Useful Area = (Perimeter × Height) - (All Windows Area + All Doors Area). Add reserve 10-15%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for plaster?
faqItems.a: Wall area for plaster calculated similarly: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. For plaster account wall irregularities: for even walls reserve 10%, for uneven - 15-20%. Include in calculation wall areas under ceiling and above floor (if leveling required).

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area in irregular shape room?
faqItems.a: Break room into simple geometric figures (rectangles, triangles). Calculate perimeter of each part. For corner rooms use "3 walls" option. For open spaces - "2 walls". Sum areas of all parts. Subtract openings and add reserve.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for panel installation?
faqItems.a: Calculation similar to tile: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. For panels account their width and mounting method. Vertical panels: reserve 10-15%. Horizontal panels with cutting: reserve 15-20%. Account for cutting in corners and around openings.

faqItems.q: Should ceiling area be accounted for when calculating walls?
faqItems.a: No, ceiling area calculated separately. Formula: Length × Width. But if wall finishing extends to ceiling (for example, wallpaper or panels), account transition zone. Usually 5-10 cm along room perimeter.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for decorative plaster?
faqItems.a: Area calculated standard: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. For decorative plaster reserve 10-15%. Account application complexity: for textured coatings may require larger reserve (up to 20%) due to uneven application.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for bathroom painting?
faqItems.a: For bathroom measure all walls. Usually bathroom has 4 walls, but can be corner (3 walls). Calculate: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15-20%. In bathroom often no windows, but door opening exists. Use moisture-resistant paint and account application complexity.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for kitchen finishing?
faqItems.a: For kitchen account backsplash (wall above countertop) and common walls. Calculate total area: perimeter × height. Subtract windows and doors. Backsplash usually has height 60-90 cm and calculated separately. For kitchen reserve 10-15% due to relief complexity.

faqItems.q: How to calculate hallway wall area?
faqItems.a: Hallway usually has 2 parallel walls (long sides) or 4 walls (if closed). Measure hallway length and width, height. Calculate perimeter. If hallway open on one side - use "2 walls" option. Account all doors in hallway. Reserve 10%.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for children's room?
faqItems.a: Standard calculation: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. For children's room account material safety (eco-friendliness). Measure all walls, accounting niches and protrusions. For bright patterned wallpaper reserve 15-20% due to need for pattern matching.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for office finishing?
faqItems.a: For office room measure length and width. Offices often have many windows and doors. Calculate: perimeter × height - all openings + reserve 10%. Account partitions (walls between workstations), they calculated separately. For standard office ceilings (2.5-3 m) use maximum height.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for turnkey painting?
faqItems.a: Turnkey means complete finishing of all walls. Measure all walls, including hallways, utility rooms. Calculate each room separately: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. Sum all areas. Reserve for turnkey painting: 10-15%. Account number of paint layers (usually 2-3).

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for wallpaper with pattern repeat?
faqItems.a: Wall area calculated standard: perimeter × height - openings. But for wallpaper with pattern repeat larger reserve needed: 15-20% instead of 10%. Pattern repeat is repeating pattern. Larger repeat means more waste when pasting. Account pattern matching in corners and joints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for balcony painting?
faqItems.a: Balcony usually has 3 walls (two side and one facade). Measure dimensions of each wall separately. Sum areas. Account windows (usually large). Reserve 15-20% due to application complexity on small surfaces and corners. Account temperature conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for bedroom finishing?
faqItems.a: Standard bedroom 4×5 m: perimeter 18 m, height 2.7 m → area 48.6 m². Subtract window (2-3 m²) and door (2 m²) = 44-45 m² useful area. With reserve 10%: 48-50 m² material. For bedroom account material comfort and eco-friendliness.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for PVC panels?
faqItems.a: Calculation similar to tile: perimeter × height - openings + reserve. For PVC panels account their length (usually 2.7 m or 3 m) and width (10-30 cm). Reserve depends on mounting method: horizontal - 15-20%, vertical - 10-15%. Account cutting in corners.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for drywall?
faqItems.a: For drywall calculate frame area (profiles). Wall area: perimeter × height. Account that drywall mounted on frame, so account profile spacing (usually 40-60 cm). Drywall sheet area: walls + reserve 10-15% for cutting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for facade painting?
faqItems.a: For facade measure building perimeter and wall height. Account all openings (windows, doors, gates). Reserve for facade painting 15-20% due to complex working conditions and need for touch-up. Account number of layers (usually 2-3 for facade).

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for entrance hall finishing?
faqItems.a: Entrance hall (hallway) often has 2 or 4 walls. Measure length and width. If entrance hall open on one side - use "2 walls". Calculate: perimeter × height - openings (usually only door) + reserve 10%. Account narrowness of space and need for careful cutting.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for garage painting?
faqItems.a: Garage usually has 4 walls, but can be with gate (one wall missing). Measure dimensions of all walls. Account gate as opening. Area: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 10-15%. For garage use wear-resistant paint. Account operating conditions.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for liquid wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Liquid wallpaper applied like plaster. Calculation: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15-20%. Liquid wallpaper requires larger reserve due to application features and possible irregularities. Account consumption per 1 m² (usually indicated on package) and number of layers.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for store finishing?
faqItems.a: For store measure all walls of sales floor and utility rooms. Calculate each room separately: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 10-15%. Sum all areas. Account showcases (large openings) and need for durable finishing. For store material wear resistance is important.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for basement painting?
faqItems.a: Basement can have different configuration. Measure all walls. Account humidity and need for waterproofing. Area: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15-20%. For basement use special paints (anti-fungal, moisture-resistant). Basement height usually lower than standard (2-2.5 m).

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for attic finishing?
faqItems.a: Attic has complex shape with sloped walls. Break walls into simple figures. For sloped walls measure average height or calculate triangular sections separately. Area: sum of all sections - openings + reserve 15-20%. Account application complexity on sloped surfaces.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for pantry painting?
faqItems.a: Pantry usually small room. Standard calculation: perimeter × height - openings (usually only door) + reserve 10%. Account small pantry dimensions and need to save materials. For pantry can use simpler finishing materials.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for restaurant finishing?
faqItems.a: For restaurant measure all rooms: hall, kitchen, utility rooms. Calculate each separately: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15%. For hall account specific requirements (easy cleaning, fire safety). For kitchen - moisture-resistant materials. Sum areas of all rooms.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for cafe painting?
faqItems.a: Similarly to restaurant: measure hall and utility rooms. Perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15%. For cafe wear resistance and easy surface cleaning important. Account room specifics (high traffic, humidity). Recommended to use washable paints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for sauna finishing?
faqItems.a: For sauna measure all steam room walls. Account high temperature and humidity. Area: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15-20%. For sauna special materials used (wood paneling, special paints). Account need for ventilation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for loggia balcony painting?
faqItems.a: Loggia differs from balcony: it is built into building and has 3 walls (or 4, if closed). Measure all walls. Account windows. Area: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15-20%. For loggia use frost-resistant materials. Account insulation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for bathhouse finishing?
faqItems.a: For bathhouse measure steam room and washing room separately. Steam room: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 20%. Washing room: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 15-20%. Use moisture-resistant and heat-resistant materials (wood paneling, special paints). Account complex conditions (high humidity, temperature).

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for stairwell painting?
faqItems.a: Stairwell has complex configuration. Measure perimeter on each floor. Account stair flights and landings. Area: perimeter × height - openings (windows, doors) + reserve 15%. For stairwell wear resistance and easy cleaning important. Use washable paints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for gym finishing?
faqItems.a: For gym measure perimeter of large room. Usually gyms have high ceilings (3-5 m). Area: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 10-15%. Account material requirements (strength, wear resistance). For gym specialized coatings used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for attic painting?
faqItems.a: Attic has complex shape with sloped walls. Break into simple sections. For sloped walls measure average height. Area: sum of all sections - openings + reserve 15-20%. Account application complexity on sloped surfaces. For attic usually simple materials used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for industrial room finishing?
faqItems.a: For industrial room measure large perimeter. Height usually higher than standard (3-6 m). Area: perimeter × height - openings (gates, windows) + reserve 10-15%. Account safety requirements (fire resistance, wear resistance). Use specialized industrial paints.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for painting before wallpaper?
faqItems.a: Before wallpapering walls usually primed and painted. Area: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 10%. Primer applied in 1-2 layers, paint under wallpaper - in 1 layer. Account primer and paint consumption per m² (usually indicated on package). Reserve needed for quality surface preparation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate wall area for studio apartment finishing?
faqItems.a: Studio is large room without partitions. Measure total perimeter and height. Account zoning (may be partial separation). Area: perimeter × height - openings + reserve 10-15%. Account large area and need for uniform finishing. For studio accent walls often used.

tips.title: Useful Tips
tips.supply: Supply ventilation should provide fresh air intake
tips.exhaust: Exhaust ventilation removes contaminated air from room
tips.balance: Balance of supply and exhaust ventilation ensures normal air exchange
tips.consult: For complex facilities specialist consultation recommended

seo.title: Ventilation Calculator - Calculate Room Ventilation | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online ventilation calculator. Calculate ventilation capacity for residential, office and industrial premises. Accounts for room volume, type, number of people.
seo.keywords: ventilation calculator, ventilation calculation, ventilation capacity, air exchange rate, room ventilation calculation, apartment ventilation, house ventilation, supply ventilation, exhaust ventilation, mechanical ventilation, natural ventilation, air exchange calculation, fan capacity, kitchen ventilation, bathroom ventilation, office ventilation, restaurant ventilation, gym ventilation, industrial premises ventilation, ventilation system, ventilation design, online ventilation calculation, air exchange calculator, ventilation volume, air exchange rate, air exchange in room, bathroom ventilation calculation, children's room ventilation, bedroom ventilation, living room ventilation

overview.title: Ventilation Calculator
overview.content: Online ventilation calculator will help calculate required ventilation system capacity for various room types. Accounts for room volume, type (living room, kitchen, bathroom, office, etc.), number of people and air exchange rate. Suitable for calculating supply, exhaust and combined ventilation.
overview.additionalContent: Ventilation calculator uses standard air exchange rates for different room types according to building codes. Calculation formula: Room Volume = Length × Width × Height, Capacity by Volume = Volume × Air Exchange Rate, Capacity by People = Number of People × Air Rate per Person, Required Capacity = max(By Volume, By People). Different air exchange rate standards apply for different room types.

calculationExamples.title: Ventilation Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of ventilation calculation for various premises:

example1.title: Example 1: Living Room 4×5 m
example1.description: Bedroom or living room of standard size, height 2.7 m
example1.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 5 m, Height: 2.7 m
Type: Living Room
Number of People: 2
Air Exchange Rate: 1 time/h (auto)
Air Rate per Person: 30 m³/h (auto)
example1.calculation:
Volume: 4 × 5 × 2.7 = 54 m³
By Volume: 54 × 1 = 54 m³/h
By People: 2 × 30 = 60 m³/h
Required: max(54, 60) = 60 m³/h
example1.note: For living room natural ventilation or small supply-exhaust system is usually sufficient

example2.title: Example 2: Kitchen 3×4 m with Hood
example2.description: Kitchen of standard size with gas stove, height 2.7 m
example2.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 4 m, Height: 2.7 m
Type: Kitchen
Number of People: 1
Air Exchange Rate: 3 times/h (auto)
Air Rate per Person: 60 m³/h (auto)
example2.calculation:
Volume: 3 × 4 × 2.7 = 32.4 m³
By Volume: 32.4 × 3 = 97.2 m³/h
By People: 1 × 60 = 60 m³/h
Required: max(97.2, 60) = 97.2 m³/h
example2.note: For kitchen exhaust ventilation above stove with capacity not less than 90 m³/h is required

example3.title: Example 3: Bathroom 2×2 m
example3.description: Small bathroom, height 2.5 m
example3.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 2 m, Height: 2.5 m
Type: Bathroom/Toilet
Number of People: 1
Air Exchange Rate: 3 times/h (auto)
Air Rate per Person: 25 m³/h (auto)
example3.calculation:
Volume: 2 × 2 × 2.5 = 10 m³
By Volume: 10 × 3 = 30 m³/h
By People: 1 × 25 = 25 m³/h
Required: max(30, 25) = 30 m³/h
example3.note: For bathroom exhaust ventilation with capacity not less than 25 m³/h is required

example4.title: Example 4: Office 6×8 m
example4.description: Open-plan office for 10 employees, height 3 m
example4.input:
Length: 6 m, Width: 8 m, Height: 3 m
Type: Office
Number of People: 10
Air Exchange Rate: 2 times/h (auto)
Air Rate per Person: 40 m³/h (auto)
example4.calculation:
Volume: 6 × 8 × 3 = 144 m³
By Volume: 144 × 2 = 288 m³/h
By People: 10 × 40 = 400 m³/h
Required: max(288, 400) = 400 m³/h
example4.note: For office premises mechanical supply-exhaust ventilation with air filtration is required

example5.title: Example 5: Restaurant Hall 10×12 m
example5.description: Restaurant hall for 50 visitors, height 3.5 m
example5.input:
Length: 10 m, Width: 12 m, Height: 3.5 m
Type: Restaurant/Cafe
Number of People: 50
Air Exchange Rate: 5 times/h (auto)
Air Rate per Person: 60 m³/h (auto)
example5.calculation:
Volume: 10 × 12 × 3.5 = 420 m³
By Volume: 420 × 5 = 2100 m³/h
By People: 50 × 60 = 3000 m³/h
Required: max(2100, 3000) = 3000 m³/h
example5.note: For restaurant powerful supply-exhaust ventilation with odor and excess heat removal is required

example6.title: Example 6: Gym 8×10 m
example6.description: Gym for training, height 4 m
example6.input:
Length: 8 m, Width: 10 m, Height: 4 m
Type: Gym
Number of People: 15
Air Exchange Rate: 4 times/h (auto)
Air Rate per Person: 80 m³/h (auto)
example6.calculation:
Volume: 8 × 10 × 4 = 320 m³
By Volume: 320 × 4 = 1280 m³/h
By People: 15 × 80 = 1200 m³/h
Required: max(1280, 1200) = 1280 m³/h
example6.note: For gym intensive ventilation for carbon dioxide and moisture removal is required, capacity not less than 4 times/h

calculation.title: How Ventilation Is Calculated
calculation.content: Ventilation calculation includes several steps to determine required ventilation system capacity.
calculation.capacityByVolume: Capacity by Volume = Volume × Air Exchange Rate
calculation.capacityByPeople: Capacity by People = Number of People × Air Rate per Person
calculation.requiredCapacity: Required Capacity = max(By Volume, By People)

advantages.title: Calculator Advantages
advantages.content: Using ventilation calculator provides many advantages when designing ventilation systems.

health.title: Health and Comfort
health.description: Properly calculated ventilation provides clean air, removes contaminants and moisture, creates comfortable conditions for people.

efficiency.title: Energy Efficiency
efficiency.description: Accurate calculation allows choosing optimal ventilation capacity, which reduces energy consumption and operating costs.

comfort.title: Comfortable Microclimate
comfort.description: Adequate ventilation maintains optimal temperature, humidity and air quality in room.

tips.title: Ventilation Installation Tips
tips.content: For efficient ventilation system operation follow our recommendations:

system.natural: Natural ventilation is suitable for small residential premises with low pollution
system.mechanical: Mechanical ventilation is necessary for offices, restaurants, industrial premises
system.combined: Combined system combines natural and mechanical ventilation

installation.ducts: Air ducts should be minimal length and with minimal bends
installation.location: Place supply grilles in living area, exhaust - in contaminated areas
installation.noise: Use silencers to reduce mechanical ventilation noise level

maintenance.cleaning: Regularly clean air ducts and grilles from dust and contaminants
maintenance.filters: Replace filters in supply ventilation at least once every 3-6 months
maintenance.check: Check fan and damper operation at least once a year

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for apartment?
faqItems.a: Calculate ventilation for each room separately: bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom. For living rooms rate is 1 time/h, for kitchen 3 times/h, for bathroom 3 times/h. Sum capacity of all rooms. Example: apartment 60 m², height 2.7 m → total volume 162 m³, required capacity ~200 m³/h for entire apartment.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation capacity?
faqItems.a: Capacity = Room Volume × Air Exchange Rate or Number of People × Air Rate per Person. Take maximum value. Example: room 4×5×2.7 m = 54 m³, rate 1 time/h → capacity 54 m³/h. If room has 2 people at 30 m³/h each → 60 m³/h, take 60 m³/h.

faqItems.q: What air exchange rate for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen air exchange rate is 3 times/h for general ventilation and additionally hood above stove with capacity not less than 90 m³/h (for gas stove) or 60 m³/h (for electric stove) is required. Hood works independently from general ventilation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for office?
faqItems.a: For office air exchange rate is 2 times/h, air rate per person 40 m³/h. Calculate: office volume × 2 or number of employees × 40, take maximum value. For office for 20 people, area 100 m², height 3 m → volume 300 m³, by volume 600 m³/h, by people 800 m³/h, required 800 m³/h.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For bathroom rate is 3 times/h, rate per person 25 m³/h. Bathroom 2×2×2.5 m = 10 m³, capacity 10×3 = 30 m³/h. Exhaust ventilation is required, supply not needed (air comes from other rooms). Exhaust fan with timer is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate natural ventilation?
faqItems.a: Natural ventilation works due to temperature and pressure difference. Capacity calculation is complex, depends on many factors. Usually natural ventilation provides 0.5-1 time/h air exchange. For accurate calculation consider ventilation channel area, temperature difference, wind direction.

faqItems.q: How to calculate mechanical ventilation?
faqItems.a: Mechanical ventilation is calculated as volume × rate or people × rate. Fan capacity should match calculated. Example: room 50 m³, rate 3 times/h → need fan with capacity 150 m³/h. Account for losses in ducts (10-20%), add margin.

faqItems.q: How to calculate supply-exhaust ventilation?
faqItems.a: Supply-exhaust ventilation should be balanced: supply ≈ exhaust. Calculate required capacity. Supply ventilation: 100% of required. Exhaust: 90-100% of supply. Example: required 100 m³/h → supply 100 m³/h, exhaust 90-100 m³/h. Small imbalance (5-10%) is allowed to prevent drafts.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for restaurant?
faqItems.a: For restaurant rate is 5 times/h, rate per person 60 m³/h. Hall 10×12×3.5 m = 420 m³, by volume 420×5 = 2100 m³/h. With 50 visitors: 50×60 = 3000 m³/h. Required: 3000 m³/h. Powerful supply-exhaust ventilation with odor removal from kitchen and hall is needed, additionally hood above kitchen equipment.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for gym?
faqItems.a: For gym rate is 4 times/h, rate per person 80 m³/h. Gym 8×10×4 m = 320 m³, by volume 320×4 = 1280 m³/h. With 15 training: 15×80 = 1200 m³/h. Required: 1280 m³/h. Intensive ventilation for carbon dioxide, moisture and excess heat removal is needed. Mechanical supply-exhaust system is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for industrial premises?
faqItems.a: For industrial premises rate is 3-6 times/h depending on production type and hazards. Calculate by volume and add local exhaust. Example: workshop 20×15×4 m = 1200 m³, rate 4 times/h → 4800 m³/h. Account for local exhausts from equipment. For hazardous industries rate can be up to 10-20 times/h.

faqItems.q: How to calculate air exchange in room?
faqItems.a: Air exchange = Ventilation Capacity / Room Volume. Example: capacity 100 m³/h, volume 50 m³ → air exchange 100/50 = 2 times/h. Air exchange rate shows how many times per hour air in room is completely replaced. Rate for living rooms: 1 time/h, for kitchen: 3 times/h, for bathroom: 3 times/h.

faqItems.q: How to calculate fan capacity?
faqItems.a: Fan capacity should match required ventilation capacity accounting for losses in ducts. Required capacity × (1 + losses). Losses in ducts usually 10-20%. Example: required 100 m³/h, losses 15% → fan should be 100×1.15 = 115 m³/h. Choose fan with capacity slightly higher than calculated.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for children's room?
faqItems.a: For children's room rate is 1 time/h, rate per child 30 m³/h. Children's room 3×4×2.7 m = 32.4 m³, capacity 32.4×1 = 32.4 m³/h. For one child: 1×30 = 30 m³/h. Required: 32.4 m³/h. Supply-exhaust ventilation with filtration for clean air is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for bedroom?
faqItems.a: For bedroom rate is 1 time/h, rate per person 30 m³/h. Bedroom 4×5×2.7 m = 54 m³, capacity 54×1 = 54 m³/h. For two people: 2×30 = 60 m³/h. Required: 60 m³/h. For bedroom natural ventilation or quiet mechanical supply-exhaust system is sufficient. Fan quietness is important.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for living room?
faqItems.a: For living room rate is 1 time/h, rate per person 30 m³/h. Living room 6×8×2.7 m = 129.6 m³, capacity 130×1 = 130 m³/h. For 4-5 people: 5×30 = 150 m³/h. Required: 150 m³/h. For large living room mechanical ventilation for comfortable microclimate is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for kitchen with gas stove?
faqItems.a: For kitchen with gas stove hood with capacity not less than 90 m³/h above stove is required. General kitchen ventilation: volume × 3 times/h. Example: kitchen 3×4×2.7 m = 32.4 m³, general ventilation 32.4×3 = 97.2 m³/h, hood above stove 90 m³/h. Hood works independently, turns on when cooking.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for kitchen with electric stove?
faqItems.a: For kitchen with electric stove hood should have capacity not less than 60 m³/h. General ventilation: volume × 3 times/h. Kitchen 3×4×2.7 m = 32.4 m³, general ventilation 97.2 m³/h, hood 60 m³/h. Electric stove produces fewer harmful substances, so hood can be lower power.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for bathroom/toilet?
faqItems.a: For bathroom/toilet rate is 3 times/h, rate per person 25 m³/h. Bathroom/toilet 2×2×2.5 m = 10 m³, capacity 10×3 = 30 m³/h. Exhaust ventilation is required, supply not needed (air comes from other rooms through door gaps). Exhaust fan with humidity sensor is recommended.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for office building?
faqItems.a: For office building calculate each room separately, then sum. Office: rate 2 times/h, rate 40 m³/h per person. For multi-story office building centralized supply-exhaust system with heat recovery is required. Central system capacity = sum of all rooms. Account for losses in main ducts.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for store?
faqItems.a: For store rate depends on type: grocery 2-3 times/h, non-grocery 1-2 times/h. Rate per visitor 40-60 m³/h depending on area. Sales floor 100 m², height 3 m = 300 m³, rate 2 times/h → 600 m³/h. With 30 visitors: 30×50 = 1500 m³/h. Required: 1500 m³/h. Supply-exhaust ventilation with heat recovery is needed.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for warehouse?
faqItems.a: For warehouse rate is 1 time/h for regular warehouses, 2-3 times/h for warehouses with chemicals. Warehouse 20×30×5 m = 3000 m³, rate 1 time/h → 3000 m³/h. For regular warehouses natural ventilation through gates and windows is sufficient. For warehouses with hazardous substances mechanical supply-exhaust ventilation is required.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for cafe?
faqItems.a: For cafe rate is 5 times/h, rate per visitor 60 m³/h. Cafe hall 8×10×3 m = 240 m³, by volume 240×5 = 1200 m³/h. With 30 visitors: 30×60 = 1800 m³/h. Required: 1800 m³/h. Powerful supply-exhaust ventilation for odor and excess heat removal is needed. Additionally hood above kitchen equipment.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for sauna?
faqItems.a: For sauna rate is 5-10 times/h for steam room, 3-5 times/h for changing room. Steam room 2×2×2.2 m = 8.8 m³, rate 7 times/h → 61.6 m³/h. Exhaust ventilation for moisture and carbon dioxide removal is required. Supply ventilation should supply small amount of air (10-20% of exhaust) to prevent drafts.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for bathhouse?
faqItems.a: For bathhouse steam room: rate 5-10 times/h, washroom: 3-5 times/h. Steam room 3×4×2.2 m = 26.4 m³, rate 7 times/h → 185 m³/h. Washroom 3×3×2.5 m = 22.5 m³, rate 4 times/h → 90 m³/h. Powerful exhaust ventilation for moisture removal is needed. Use fans with moisture protection (IP65).

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for swimming pool?
faqItems.a: For swimming pool rate is 3-5 times/h, rate 80 m³/h per visitor. Pool 10×20×3 m = 600 m³, rate 4 times/h → 2400 m³/h. With 10 visitors: 10×80 = 800 m³/h. Required: 2400 m³/h. Supply-exhaust ventilation with air dehumidification for excess moisture removal is needed. Specialized equipment for pools is used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for production workshop?
faqItems.a: For production workshop rate is 3-10 times/h depending on production hazards. Workshop 30×20×6 m = 3600 m³, rate 4 times/h → 14400 m³/h. For hazardous industries rate can be up to 20 times/h. Account for local exhausts from equipment. Specialized ventilation system design is required.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for laboratory?
faqItems.a: For laboratory rate is 4-6 times/h, rate 40-60 m³/h per worker. Laboratory 5×6×2.8 m = 84 m³, rate 5 times/h → 420 m³/h. With 3 workers: 3×50 = 150 m³/h. Required: 420 m³/h. Supply-exhaust ventilation with filtration and local exhausts from fume hoods is needed. Air should not recirculate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for classroom?
faqItems.a: For classroom rate is 2 times/h, rate 40 m³/h per student. Classroom 8×6×3 m = 144 m³, rate 2 times/h → 288 m³/h. With 25 students: 25×40 = 1000 m³/h. Required: 1000 m³/h. Mechanical supply-exhaust ventilation for fresh air and comfortable learning conditions is needed.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for cinema?
faqItems.a: For cinema rate is 4-5 times/h, rate 40 m³/h per viewer. Hall 15×20×4 m = 1200 m³, rate 4 times/h → 4800 m³/h. With 100 viewers: 100×40 = 4000 m³/h. Required: 4800 m³/h. Powerful supply-exhaust ventilation for carbon dioxide, moisture removal and viewer comfort is needed.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for basement?
faqItems.a: For basement rate is 1-2 times/h depending on purpose. Basement 10×8×2.5 m = 200 m³, rate 1.5 times/h → 300 m³/h. For basement exhaust ventilation for moisture removal and dampness prevention is important. Supply ventilation can be natural through special channels.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for attic?
faqItems.a: For attic rate is 0.5-1 time/h. Attic usually ventilated naturally through dormer windows and ventilation grilles. Attic volume is large, so even small rate gives high capacity. Attic 15×10×3 m = 450 m³, rate 0.5 time/h → 225 m³/h. Ensuring draft for moisture removal is important.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for garage?
faqItems.a: For garage rate is 2-4 times/h depending on usage. Garage 6×4×2.5 m = 60 m³, rate 3 times/h → 180 m³/h. For garage with running engine rate should be not less than 4 times/h. Exhaust ventilation for exhaust gas removal is required. Supply ventilation natural through gates.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for laundry?
faqItems.a: For laundry rate is 5-7 times/h for moisture removal. Laundry 4×5×2.8 m = 56 m³, rate 6 times/h → 336 m³/h. Powerful exhaust ventilation for excess moisture removal is needed. Supply ventilation should supply heated air to prevent condensation. Fans with moisture protection are used.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for server room?
faqItems.a: For server room rate is 3-5 times/h, rate 80-100 m³/h per 1 kW equipment. Server room 4×5×3 m = 60 m³, rate 4 times/h → 240 m³/h. With equipment power 10 kW: 10×90 = 900 m³/h. Required: 900 m³/h. Supply-exhaust ventilation with air conditioning for excess heat removal from servers is needed.

faqItems.q: How to calculate ventilation for boiler room?
faqItems.a: For boiler room rate is 3 times/h, additionally combustion air is required (for gas boilers 1 m³ air per 1 kW power). Boiler room 5×4×3 m = 60 m³, rate 3 times/h → 180 m³/h. For 24 kW boiler additionally 24 m³/h combustion air is required. Required: 204 m³/h. Supply ventilation for combustion air supply is required.

seo.title: Tile Calculator Online — Calculate Tile Quantity for Floor and Walls | Calc1.ru
seo.description: Free online tile calculator for accurate calculation of ceramic tile, porcelain stoneware and mosaic quantity for floor and walls. Accounts for room dimensions, tile size, grout width and reserve for cutting.

overview.title: Tile Calculator Online
overview.content: Online tile calculator will help calculate required tile quantity for floor or wall installation. Accounts for room dimensions, tile dimensions, grout width between tiles and reserve for cutting and possible defects.
overview.additionalContent: Tile calculator uses accurate formulas for material quantity calculation accounting for surface type, installation method and working conditions. Suitable for calculating various tile types: ceramic, porcelain stoneware, mosaic, vinyl. Calculation formula: Total Tile Quantity = (Room Area / One Tile Area) × (1 + Reserve / 100).

calculationExamples.title: Tile Calculation Examples
calculationExamples.content: Let's consider practical examples of tile quantity calculation for various rooms and tile types:

example1.title: Example 1: Bathroom 3×2 meters
example1.description: Standard bathroom with ceramic tile 30×30 cm
example1.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 2 m
Tile: 30×30 cm
Per Package: 10 pcs
Reserve: 10%
Grout Width: 2 mm
example1.calculation:
Room Area: 3 × 2 = 6 m²
Tile Area: 0.3 × 0.3 = 0.09 m²
Tile Quantity: 6 / 0.09 = 66.7 ≈ 67 pcs
With Reserve: 67 × 1.1 = 73.7 ≈ 74 pcs
Packages: 74 / 10 = 7.4 ≈ 8 packages
example1.note: Standard bathroom, recommend taking 8-9 packages with small reserve

example2.title: Example 2: Kitchen 4×3 meters
example2.description: Kitchen with porcelain stoneware 60×60 cm
example2.input:
Length: 4 m, Width: 3 m
Tile: 60×60 cm
Per Package: 4 pcs
Reserve: 10%
Grout Width: 3 mm
example2.calculation:
Room Area: 4 × 3 = 12 m²
Tile Area: 0.6 × 0.6 = 0.36 m²
Tile Quantity: 12 / 0.36 = 33.3 ≈ 34 pcs
With Reserve: 34 × 1.1 = 37.4 ≈ 38 pcs
Packages: 38 / 4 = 9.5 ≈ 10 packages
example2.note: For kitchen better choose moisture-resistant porcelain stoneware and increase reserve to 15%

example3.title: Example 3: Hallway 2×1.5 meters
example3.description: Small hallway with tile 20×30 cm
example3.input:
Length: 2 m, Width: 1.5 m
Tile: 20×30 cm
Per Package: 15 pcs
Reserve: 10%
Grout Width: 2 mm
example3.calculation:
Room Area: 2 × 1.5 = 3 m²
Tile Area: 0.2 × 0.3 = 0.06 m²
Tile Quantity: 3 / 0.06 = 50 pcs
With Reserve: 50 × 1.1 = 55 pcs
Packages: 55 / 15 = 3.7 ≈ 4 packages
example3.note: For hallway wear-resistant tile is recommended

example4.title: Example 4: Kitchen Backsplash 3×0.6 meters
example4.description: Backsplash above work surface with mosaic 10×10 cm
example4.input:
Length: 3 m, Width: 0.6 m
Tile: 10×10 cm
Per Package: 100 pcs
Reserve: 15%
Grout Width: 2 mm
example4.calculation:
Room Area: 3 × 0.6 = 1.8 m²
Tile Area: 0.1 × 0.1 = 0.01 m²
Tile Quantity: 1.8 / 0.01 = 180 pcs
With Reserve: 180 × 1.15 = 207 pcs
Packages: 207 / 100 = 2.07 ≈ 3 packages
example4.note: For backsplash glass or ceramic mosaic is recommended

example5.title: Example 5: Living Room Floor 5×4 meters
example5.description: Large living room with large-format tile 80×80 cm
example5.input:
Length: 5 m, Width: 4 m
Tile: 80×80 cm
Per Package: 2 pcs
Reserve: 10%
Grout Width: 3 mm
example5.calculation:
Room Area: 5 × 4 = 20 m²
Tile Area: 0.8 × 0.8 = 0.64 m²
Tile Quantity: 20 / 0.64 = 31.25 ≈ 32 pcs
With Reserve: 32 × 1.1 = 35.2 ≈ 36 pcs
Packages: 36 / 2 = 18 packages
example5.note: For large rooms better use large-format tile for visual space expansion

example6.title: Example 6: Bathroom with Niches
example6.description: Bathroom with niches for shelves, tile 25×40 cm
example6.input:
Length: 3.5 m, Width: 2.5 m
Niches Area: 2 m²
Tile: 25×40 cm
Per Package: 12 pcs
Reserve: 15%
Grout Width: 2 mm
example6.calculation:
Room Area: 3.5 × 2.5 = 8.75 m²
Useful Area: 8.75 - 2 = 6.75 m²
Tile Area: 0.25 × 0.4 = 0.1 m²
Tile Quantity: 6.75 / 0.1 = 67.5 ≈ 68 pcs
With Reserve: 68 × 1.15 = 78.2 ≈ 79 pcs
Packages: 79 / 12 = 6.6 ≈ 7 packages
example6.note: With niches and corners recommend increasing reserve to 15%

calculation.title: How Tile Quantity Is Calculated
calculation.content: Tile quantity calculation includes several steps to get accurate result accounting for all room parameters and tile type.
calculation.tile: Tile Quantity = Room Area / One Tile Area
calculation.packages: Package Quantity = Tile Quantity / Quantity per Package

tips.title: Tile Calculation Tips
tips.content: For accurate result follow our recommendations when calculating tiles.

measurement.title: Measurements
measurement.area: Account for niches, protrusions and complex shapes

installation.title: Installation
installation.pattern: For patterned tiles increase reserve to 20%

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile quantity for floor?
faqItems.a: To calculate tiles measure room length and width, select tile size and specify tiles per package. Calculator will automatically calculate required number of packages accounting for reserve for cutting.

faqItems.q: How much tile needed for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For standard bathroom 3×2 meters with tile 30×30 cm need approximately 7-8 packages (10 tiles per package) accounting for 10% reserve. Exact quantity depends on room dimensions and tile size.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for walls?
faqItems.a: To calculate tile for walls measure height and width of each wall, subtract windows and doors area. Then calculate tile quantity using same formula as for floor.

faqItems.q: What tile reserve is needed?
faqItems.a: Reserve 10-15% is recommended for regular tile and 15-20% for patterned tile or complex shapes. Reserve accounts for cutting, defects and possible installation errors.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen measure floor and backsplash area separately. For floor use wear-resistant porcelain stoneware, for backsplash - decorative tile or mosaic. Calculate each area separately.

faqItems.q: What is difference between ceramic tile and porcelain stoneware?
faqItems.a: Porcelain stoneware is more durable and wear-resistant than ceramic tile. It has lower water absorption and suitable for high-traffic areas. Ceramic tile is suitable for walls and low-traffic areas.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for bathroom with niches?
faqItems.a: Measure total bathroom area, then subtract niches and protrusions area. Add 15% reserve for complex shapes and corners. Calculate tile quantity using standard formula.

faqItems.q: How many tiles in package?
faqItems.a: Number of tiles per package depends on tile size. For example, tile 30×30 cm usually packaged 10-15 pcs, tile 60×60 cm - 2-4 pcs. Exact information is on package.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile quantity for diagonal installation?
faqItems.a: With diagonal installation consumption increases by 15-20% compared to straight installation. Increase material reserve and use calculator accounting for additional consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for heated floor?
faqItems.a: For heated floor recommend using porcelain stoneware with thickness not less than 8 mm. Tile quantity calculation is same as for regular floor, but account for tile thickness for correct installation.

faqItems.q: Какая ширина шва нужна для плитки?
faqItems.a: Ширина шва зависит от размера плитки: для плитки до 30 см - 2-3 мм, для плитки 30-60 см - 3-5 мм, для крупноформатной плитки - 5-10 мм. Ширина шва влияет на расход затирки.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for mosaic?
faqItems.a: Mosaic is packaged in sheets or rolls. Measure surface area, calculate number of sheets accounting for 15-20% reserve. Mosaic requires larger reserve due to installation complexity.

faqItems.q: How much does tile cost for bathroom?
faqItems.a: Tile cost depends on type, size and manufacturer. Ceramic tile costs from $2 to $10/m², porcelain stoneware - from $5 to $30/m². Calculate area and multiply by price per m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for hallway?
faqItems.a: For hallway measure length and width. Account for complex shape and corners. Add 15% reserve for cutting. Recommend using wear-resistant tile for high traffic.

faqItems.q: What is rectified tile?
faqItems.a: Rectified tile has processed edges for minimal grout (1-2 mm). It creates seamless surface effect. It needs smaller material reserve, but requires precise installation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for balcony?
faqItems.a: For balcony measure floor and wall area (if needed). Use frost-resistant tile for exterior work. Add 15% reserve for complex shapes and corners.

faqItems.q: Should windows and doors be considered when calculating tile for walls?
faqItems.a: Yes, when calculating tile for walls always subtract windows and doors area from total wall area. This reduces material consumption and cost.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for stairs?
faqItems.a: For stairs calculate area of each step and riser separately. Account for cutting necessity. Add 20% reserve for complex step shape.

faqItems.q: What tile is better for kitchen?
faqItems.a: For kitchen recommend porcelain stoneware with low water absorption and high wear resistance. Tile size depends on kitchen size: for small - 30×30 cm, for large - 60×60 cm.

faqItems.q: Как рассчитать плитку для гостиной?
faqItems.a: Для гостиной измерьте площадь пола. Выберите крупноформатную плитку 60×60 или 80×80 см для визуального расширения пространства. Добавьте запас 10% для обычной укладки.

faqItems.q: What is wood-look tile?
faqItems.a: Wood-look tile imitates wooden flooring but has all advantages of ceramic tile. It is installed like regular tile, quantity calculation is same.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for bathroom with bathtub?
faqItems.a: For bathroom with bathtub calculate floor and wall area separately. For walls around bathtub use moisture-resistant tile. Subtract bathtub area from floor area.

faqItems.q: How many tiles needed per 1 m²?
faqItems.a: Number of tiles per 1 m² depends on tile size. For example, tile 30×30 cm - 11.1 pcs/m², tile 60×60 cm - 2.78 pcs/m². Use formula: 1 m² / tile area.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for shower cabin?
faqItems.a: For shower cabin measure floor area and all walls inside cabin. Use moisture-resistant tile or mosaic. Add 15% reserve for complex shapes and corners.

faqItems.q: Should tile be bought with reserve?
faqItems.a: Yes, always buy tile with 10-15% reserve for cutting, defects and possible errors. Reserve helps avoid situation when several tiles are missing.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for entryway?
faqItems.a: For entryway measure floor area. Account for complex shape and corners. Recommend using wear-resistant tile for high traffic. Add 15% reserve.

faqItems.q: What is subway tile?
faqItems.a: Subway tile is rectangular tile format 10×20 cm or 7.5×15 cm. It is popular for kitchens and bathrooms. Quantity calculation is same as for regular tile.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for bedroom?
faqItems.a: For bedroom tile is rarely used, but if needed, measure floor area. Choose decorative tile or wood-look tile. Add 10% reserve for regular installation.

faqItems.q: What tile is better for bathroom?
faqItems.a: For bathroom recommend moisture-resistant ceramic tile or porcelain stoneware with low water absorption. Tile size depends on bathroom size: for small - 20×30 cm, for large - 30×60 cm.

faqItems.q: How to calculate tile for toilet?
faqItems.a: For toilet measure floor and wall area. Use moisture-resistant tile. Subtract door area. Add 10% reserve for regular installation.

faqItems.q: What is clinker tile?
faqItems.a: Clinker tile is durable clay tile with low water absorption. It is suitable for exterior work and wet rooms. Quantity calculation is same as for regular tile.
